												(Original Review)Still a bit sparse and kind of dull to play. Not sure what I'm missing here, but it doesn't seem like a very intriguing game as it stands. Will check back regularly to see improvements, patches, and addons, but I don't find it keeping my interest in it's current state.(/Original Review)HOWEVERI WILL recommend either buying this game, or keeping your eye on this game, purely based on the fact these developers go way above and beyond to try and get everyone to enjoy it. Publicly, my old review was not agreed upon and I don't mind that. But that didn't even stop these devs from contacting me to let me know they're making changes and improvements, and even personally informing me of a new expansion coming. I'm definitely going to put this on my regular checklist of perpetually updated games.I may not enjoy the game like I do for others, but the developers are top notch - something you don't see more often enough with vidya these days. I hope you guys keep the professional attitude and personal touch in the future. It puts you way above a lot of other devs, and it's something we game enthusiasts really need.Thanks, guys! Can't wait to see what's to come.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game is the best when you play with friends, but the elves are a little op. So to sum it up, there are 3 factions orcs, wood elves and humans. Every faction have a diffrent ''language'' and completly different building mechanics. I my selfe play mostly as humans, but that is because I already have all their cards. One thing that is pretty uniqe and nice with this game is that it has cards that you can buy in the main meny. These cards cost various things like, swords, magic items and beer. These items are rewarded when you kill a boss (dragon mostly) in a custom game, or if you just complete the game. So from the start you are very limited on what units and upgrades you can buy in game, and this is a very fun thing for me atleast.Now to why the wood elves are pretty op. Wood elves can build gold, stone and bushes in their base, and these resources can be rebuild right after they are mined up, this ofc makes the elves have unlimited income. Also the zombies are a super fun mechanic, when you loose alot of troops in a siege or a big battle, then those troops rise as zombies and kills everything if your not carefull.There is also a small AH function where you can trade your resources for other resources, pretty neat. Higly recommend if you have some friends to play with, but also a ton of fun by your selfe.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Game is a pleasant mix of the Total War games and Age of Empires games. The game has come a long way, and even though it still has a long way to go, the journey has been a decent one. The Dev team has only four members working on the game and they work hard as they listen to the player's suggestions. The Fantastic Four have been working really hard to make this game better from the many suggestions that players have given them, and This can only get better from this point, fingers crossed.The game ofcourse has some pros and cons so without further ado, lets get into them: Pros:-Combat Feels similar to Total War; Units have formations and most have special abilities. -Heroes/Champions are characters that can be unlocked via cards or technology advancements-In game Crafting System that allows the player to choose which technology to research as they unlock features for their                     favourite faction.-Three Diverse and interesting factions to choose from. From the Mighty Orcs to the Humble Elves. And if you want to              specialise in both offense and defense, Humans are the faction for you.-Base Building has a nice bit of Nostalgia embedded into it, as they are pleasantly similar to the awesome Age of      Empires    resource collection/management system the games are so well known for; Has the feel of playing the classic AoE     games -Graphics are decent, but they're decent enough. -Dragons-Dwarves -Zombies rise as corpses are left to rotCons:-The game has some bugs but they're not really game-breaking, fixes are on the way!-At the moment, pvp is a possibility, but sometimes its difficult to find players because of the low player count. It'll only      get better from here on, (fingers crossed) And that's about it! I don't think I missed anything as of yet, feel free to correct me if I have.

Posted: May 4, 2016
												So, my first review. I've played a few games over the years and I've never really felt inclined to write a review for any of them. Not for any particular reason, there just didn't seem a need.As for this game...- Pretty soon after loading my first skirmish I was repeatedly offered potatoes by a shifty looking peasent. Built a barn, and decided to persue a chicken farming career. Orcs must have sniffed out the little cluckers or just decided to shaft me, either way they were at the front door. - Fought them off with some archers.- Decided to build on my chicken empire so I sent the potato man to discover the new world. The wolves got him before help could arrive.- Fought off a second attack from the orcs and paused for a moment to reflect on my avian industry. That when it happened: the bodies of my felled opposition, as well as some of my own men, rose from the ground and WENT STRAIGHT FOR MY BLOODY CHICKENS!!! I thought NONE OF THAT m8, you @&^%s!!! - Skewered the zombies, killed off the wolves, then returned with my army just in time to remember I'd left the front gate open and the orcs had finished off every single peasent in the place.Lost the game...Had the most fun I've had in a video game in a very long time.ChickenFarmingSimulator/10In all seriousness, what's driving me to write this review is the dev team. I wanted to help out in my small way to support their work. I have never, in all honesty, seen one so intergrated with, or responsive to their community. Go read some of the other reviews if you don't believe me. There's a helpful reply to just about every negative review; that is rare, A+ customer service. Good work dev team. Don't ♥♥♥♥ it up.LABOURER CAN BUILD!!!!

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
Kingdom Wars 2 Battles is a real time strategy game set in fictional world with medieval accents. The game plays as you would expect a game of this genre to but a few added mechanics and an online multiplayer mode keep things fresh for players. While this isn’t a genre I am very familiar with I did find the game enjoyable, it can easily be played for hours as you spend time focusing on micromanaging your units. The game offers single player and campaign modes if you just want to enjoy it on your own.The story in the campaign mode focuses on the race of humans mainly fighting against orcs. Humanity is on the run from their aggressors, periodically making valiant stands to secure their survival. Each step of the story is told via cutscenes with voice over explaining the battle and what takes place before and after it. An interesting plot point in the game is the presence of zombies -the result of cannibalism, no doubt committed by desperate war-refugees. The story itself is currently one episode with five chapters.The game’s mechanics work very well, while I mainly played the campaign mode I also found that the multiplayer mode was a fun option for those wanting to increase the game’s replay value. The game also has a great single player mode where you can play your own adventure or a survival mode. All units in the game are under your control, even down to farm animals. The worker class mines, farms and builds while fighters help protect and progress. Both classes are important to the game as is resource and time management. The game works best with a keyboard and mouse requiring both to control the camera and click on areas of interest. Each unit and building have a large variety of actions and options available to players that help to customize gameplay experiences.The graphics in the game are simple, and even a bit dated. Character models are basic and not overly-detailed and I found some of the buildings hard to tell apart visually. Maps are also standard, nothing is bad but nothing really stands out much either. I found it a little hard to tell the tiny units on the map apart as their uniform colors were often the same. The audio in the game is fine, the characters talk when you click on them and there is some voice over as well. The music is fitting, but not memorable. I found the game to be a good way for novices such as myself to learn about real time strategy, or fans who haven’t played a game in the genre for a while. Kingdom Wars 2 Battles offers a lot of options and customizing choices to tailor gameplay to each person as well as three different races to choose from; humans, orcs and elves. No matter what option you pick the game will be fun and challenging, plus there are trading card and achievements to keep a person coming back for more. With a hands-on development team regularly updating the game, this title is a great addition to any library.This review is exclusively written for Y.A - Yolo Army, follow the group's curations here!

number of helpful: 37 of 40 people (93%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								To cut straight to the chase, this is my favorite strategy game to date, and that is not due to lack of variety. I have played a large amount of RTS such as Sins of a Solar Empire, Age of Empires, Total War, and Star Wars: Empire at War, and various others. Yet none of the above gave quite the satisfaction that Kingdom Wars 2: Battles does, and that is not due to cheap gimmicks or repetitive game play.Just to give a brief bullet point list of some of the features that I find quite enjoyable:- Faction Diversity- Unit Specialization- Fire, lots of fire- Size of maps allow many forms of combat- Zombies- Unit DiversityNow, to go over each piece individually.Faction Diversity   Each faction quite simply plays very different from each other, and while there is a slight bit of overlap, as there is in every RTS, each have their own tricks and techniques to master. For example, the Orc Faction has the highest number of soldiers per unit as well as the ability to mass produce weak units such as goblins, which can win wars of attrition if you play your cards right. On the other hand, the Human Faction has some of the tankiest units in the game but is more of a balance between Elves and Orcs than anything else. Other than their durability, their units do not stick out too much, but it is quite pivotal if you are able to compound on such. Finally, the Elves, have the lowest soldiers per unit, but also have the highest quality of units, which allow them to defeat superior numbers more often than not. Despite all of this though, each faction has balanced counters and maneuvers to use against each other, with no one strategy being undefeatable. For each move, there is a counter move, for every counter move there is another counter. In essence, balance is maintained for the most part, with no one Faction getting too far ahead of the others. Each can be phenomenal in the right player’s hands.Unit Specialization   Quite simple really, but each unit has 'levels' that they achieve when they have gained enough experience from combat. This in turn, allows you to distribute stats for that unit as you see fit, meaning that a full blown army can be as unique as you deem fit. It could be as simple as maxing out the defensive stats, or going for full out mobility... Yet each is viable in different situations, with no one configuration being the end all be all. Diversity is the word of the game.Fire  This one is much simpler than the previous item, in that it is quite self-explanatory. Archers and siege equipment can make use of fire to damage buildings, do extra damage to units, or even light the battle field itself on fire. In short, just as in real life, fire is one hell of a weapon.Map Size   There are four castle plots, one taken by each player unless there are less than four of course. Each one is in a corner of the map, with defensible positions dotted all over the place, including bridges, ruins, quarries, and npc forts. The time it takes to travel across the map isn't too long, but just long enough to make you think before emptying your garrison. Caught without an army at home, you will suffer the consequences.Zombies   A relatively new addition, these buggers form up large hordes outside your castle and in essence prolong the game unless you can circumvent them. You used to be able to direct them against your opponents with clever sacrifice of units, but they are more a field threat these days. Every unit that dies and is not looted... Well... Expect to see them again. Not only does this add some threat to the general map to consider when moving about, but it also being key to use scouts to avoid them or funnel enemies towards them. While they are destructible, they can still wreak quite a bit of havoc before being put down.Unit Diversity   Each Faction has some basic units similar to another, but even then, each have their own defining characteristics. Take spearmen for example, orcs have Impalers, elves Sentries, and humans Halberdiers. The Halberdiers lack special abilities, but have higher base stats and are able to cut down monsters and Calvary quite efficiently. Impalers on the other hand are slow and lower damage, as well as health, but have an AoE ability that can one shot a large charging Calvary force, as well as stun them, not to mention it works decently against other infantry as well. Sentries on the other hand have a stun ability, which allows them to combat Calvary and monsters while taking little damage. What we have here, are three different units designed for the same task, yet go about doing it in completely different ways. Nor are they only type to have such differences.In short, KW2 is a great RTS that gets you in the action, gives you the tools to create the army you always dreamed of commanding, and to proceed however you want. Want stealth based combat? Elves have plenty of that, and the Orc's Goblins can do such as well. Want to take a tanky approach? All three have their own methods, such as Slayers, Knights, and Grandmasters. Archers? Most definitely. Another interesting thing, is the siege equipment... But I might as well not spoil it for those who have not played yet, but suffice to say, they can be used in a variety of situations.Don't believe me on half of what I said? Try it for yourself, and you are sure to find something you enjoy here.Sincerely, The Goblin King

Posted: November 17, 2016
												A very fun, addicting, unique, challenging RTS game, the campaign is good but for me i played mostly the skirimish because that is where the real challenge is. Facing 4 AI in a free for all along with zombies is truly brutal. I would train thousands along with all the ai training thousands marching them to attack me and the other AI causing tens of thousands to die throughout the game. What did the zombies do? all those tens of thousands of troops got up and became a zombie. Talk about hardcore, not only fighting AI in extremely massive battles but also having to worry about all the massive armies that die become zombies?  Let me tell you it didnt end well for me or the ai since thousands were dead infront of everyones castle. Having to worry about the enemy along with zombies is no simple task which makes it more challenging. When you fight there are 3 parties fighting which is you, the ai, and zombies ah and some random ogres and dragons every so often. This game is a very unique RTS game that has tons of replay value and content along with the weird crafting system which i personally am not into but it does add something most RTS games dont have. To answer if the game is worth it i would say yes and would very much suggest gettng it, sure you can find other good rts games but definitely not as unique as this. I mean, you not only fight AI you also fight zombies all at the same time. Pretty dang unique if you ask me and definitely not something you will find in another game.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								For a game that is still on Alpha, it successfully manages to hook players in for a long period of time despite its early content and diversity.A game that despite its current early stage is already fully capable of projecting an enchanting medieval atmosphere throughout the entire game play either on its singleplayer or in real time multiplayer battles.Kingdom Wars 2: Battles can be seen as a huge improvement from similar game series such as The Settlers, that is also capable of defining with accuracy the true way of RTS games genre.The pros of this game:Charming and wonderful graphics that makes players feel an unique medieval atmosphere in it;A game that shows a lot of diversity so far despite its short variety available (which is understandable considering that this game is still on Alpha);Both game mechanics as well the user interface are simple and good looking;A crafting system that makes this game different from the usual RTS games genre;Good music selection that contributes to the medieval atmosphere this game has to offer visually;And last but not least, the first impression that I obtained after playing this game is that it has a bright and promising future ahead of it!The cons of this game: Lack of players; (This isn't exactly a con because with the excellency of a game like Kingdom Wars 2: Battles gives to players, it does deserve a LOT more players playing it).The game currently has bugs and lack of content that can give your opponent serious advantage over you, but such things will eventually be fixed through patches;Unstable multiplayer mode with usual de-syncs and some lag spikes from time to time.ConclusionMy conclusion on this game is a bit hard to determinate because it is far from finished, but one thing I can guarantee, that this game has potential and a promising future ahead of it!

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												This game has all of the feastures it needs to make a great game and I have had fun in the short amount of time I have played it already. I really like that the more you play the more units you can unlock through the mission rewards, and the trade centre is a great idea.  However, I do believe there are a significant number of bugs to fix as I have experienced a great deal. Pros:* Fun - Probably the most fun rts I have played in some time * Interesting buidling mechanics - I love that you can extend the outer walls and how you can go quite defensive to start* All races play very differently - I really like how different  the Orcs are, it really feels like you can make a horde* The maps are large and well balanced - They feel large at first, but it means you have to move and attack* Its hard - Im probably just rubbish at it (although I play alot of RTS), but I died on the first mission which is basically a tutorial. Thats never happened to me in a game before and I like the challenge (that was on normal mode)* Very active devs - You can see this within minutes of looking on steam and the ingame chat, its very good to seeCons:* Bugs - there are alot, but looking on steam they update frequently)* Visuals - I dont mean the gfx (which arent great), buit its quite hard to tell units apart. I think this is made slightly worse on the first campaign level as there are so many bodies, but it does get easier on the single player maps*  Units AI - The units seem to work great in smaller groups, but when you select the enmasse several dont move at all without helpTLDR; Buy it now, but it needs future support from the developers (who look super active)

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Kingdom Wars 2: Battles is an incredibly interesting concept in todays view of rts strategy games. It takes mechanics from all over, with resource nodes from games like age of empires or empire earth; huge scale combat from the total war games including the batallions of x amount of units per squad. It's so nostalgic and at the same time thrilling to play a game like this. As much as I'd like to praise it up to the stars and call it the new messiah, I can't do that fairly. So let's look at some of the negatives I've noticed during gameplay.- Archers: These guys are useful, but good god can they not aim at times. If you stick them on a wall, sure they'll aim as well as they can, but when you have about 3 orcish marauders (orc archers) left in a squad firing at your 5 squads on a wall, and killing them like flies while hundreds of arrows rain down upon the orcish invaders, and not a single one is hitting them, it's a little bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥. It's not even a case of them having godly luck by dodging, the archers just don't aim at them. They aim a bit to the left, or a bit to the right, and every single arrow aims in that spot instead of where the enemy is actually standing! It's infuriating! The siege is the same too, missing countless shots and wasting ammunition to try and flatten the ground next to the invader. AGH!- Terrain: This is a little bugbear of mine, but it still counts in this. On some maps you play singleplayer, I've found that if I try to play humans, and have stone walls defending the core of my city, I can't place anyone on the outer layer. By outer layer I mean the humans have a kind of bastion style design. If intruders break through the outer walls, they have to break through the inner gates. But the inner gates are broken into two parts. I won't fully explain it since I'd sound like an utter moron trying to explain something I don't know about, but look it up. I'm sure there are a few images flying around of the human castles by now.- Balance: As of the current release of the game, I've found that the elves are insanely overpowered. Now, in a lot of games I've played over the years, elves can be quite dangerous, but if you try enough, they'll fall over flat on their pretty little faces. In this game? Good god. They're the same as all others, don't get me wrong. Push enough and they'll still die. But in terms of resources, they will outlast you. How? They get a building called a symbiosis tree, which allows them to CREATE resources. Yup, I really mean that. They can create gold mines, stone mines, even more berries if they so fancy. This means they can keep pumping out entire armies of powerful troops, while you're scrounging around the map desperately trying to find some gold for another squad of knights.- Walls: Useful, correct? well, not when the wall is blocking all your arrows trying to murder a single zombie battering down your damn gate, and you can't open that gate because the zombie is hitting it. Infuriating, especially as an orc, since you only get one exit out of your plateau. Truly infuriating. It's made even worse when you watch your archers arrows hit thin air way above the barricades and the enemy on the other side is perfectly safe. Worst bugbear ever.Now, I know that a lot of these problems should be solved during the next couple updates, and admittedly they'll take a while. I'm an impatient person so I want them as soon as possible, so I can enjoy this game even more. But on the whole, for the feel this game gives you when you play this, it's totally worth it in my opinion. Especially for the price right now. £10.99? I'd pay £20 for this game, just because it's brilliant, and brings back the main thing I love in games like this; strategic options. Rush them, or defend. It's your choice.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								I am a huge medieval RTS fan. It's been a very long time since we have another good medieval RTS, I can't remember the last good one released in recent years. All we have these days are those futuristic ones with guns and mechs yawn...Then I stumbled upon this game.+ Beautiful graphics. Nothing outstanding for 2015 but for a RTS game it still looks very good.+ The three factions in this game are very different from each other. Can we have more factions though? Why every RTS game these days has exactly 3 factions? I know it's quality over quantity but still!+ Great wall defense mechanics. Pouring oil down to the invaders!+ Fire arrows. Archers in this game have much more impact than just being some low-HP fire support.+ After a battle, you can send peasants to loot corpses for gold and wood. Nice.+ Interesting crafting system, with different cards for different factions.+ Good price for a game like this. Look up other recently released RTS games on Steam, they are very overpriced despite just being clones of Starcraft, C&C etc.- Variety of buildings and units, hope more will get added.- Not really a fan of the zombies. More polishing would make this a + instead of a - though.- Bugs & optimization, but not really a con here since the game is still in early access.I'm excited to see new patches and content added to this game. As of right now I cannot not consider this one of the great medieval RTS games yet, but lots of potential here, don't screw it up guys.8/10

Early Access Review
								as of: May 11, 2015A creative and inventive world with an RTS twist, it has a ton of potential but there is still a lot of work to be done on it. For now I can barely play hardly an hour. Trust me, if you are an RTS lover, this game is not. worth. 20 dollars. I promise you. I can barely play more than an hour and I will try to give you a short review on why it's not worth your time:Cons:-Very clunky main menu screen-Text is hard to read and you can't increase or decrease the size because then it will disappear-There is like, NO AA on the menu screen so everything is hard to look at. (texts are very jagged and it's headache-inducing to try and craft cards) -If you're used to most RTS games, building in this game is weirdly confusing, but I think it can be overlooked if they patched the game up some more. Obviously they're trying new techniques that's completely different from building in Age of Empires, as an example.-Voice acting -No immersion, and definitely not addictive or satisfying when it comes to RTS games.-Not quite optimized, I sadly can't even do the storymode because of extreme lag (yet when I play singleplayer, it's just fine)-A voice that constantly tells you that you have idle workers (not sure if you can turn this off yet)Pros:-Good music!-Obviously they care about their own lore and storytelling, you easily get this with how they simply give their inhuman races their snippets of their own languages-Each race is completely different -Cards: something I've never done in an RTS. Basically they're like buffs that you craft before you play a game that gives you an advantage on a map. It's pretty clever-Good maps, they look pretty and there's a good selection of them so far-Nice visuals for an RTS-If you're into the high fantasy scene, it's a good way to feel a little nostalgia from the old Warcraft daysI actually do not recommend this game to play, but to help fund the studio to make this game better because it has obvious potential. This is one reason I hope Early Access Games will stop being a thing and gaming studios will focus on the content of their game rather than pushing it out as fast as they can as an unfinished piece.

								A good fantasy real time strategy game that has a lot of potential.It feels like a combination of the two good old Age of Empireand Blitzkrieg, where you control a group of soldiers as per unitlike in Blitzkrieg and has the building, economy andupgrade system similar to that of AoE.You can play as 3 distinct factions: Human, Elves and Orcs.Since you can control group of soldiers as a unit, every battle will be huge and epic like in the movieLord of The Ring :) though they may not last very long like in Total War series because the soldierswill die fairly quickly (same as in any other RTS).Graphics is really nice, and of today gaming standard.There is a little limit with the AI as theydon't know how to attack human player so it's hard to even finish a game because they would just build a really huge armyand station them in their heavily fortified castle and wait there untill the end of earth.But since the developer's goal is to make this a multiplayer RTS game, the AI limitation can well be omitted, and probably will be improved in the future as it is still in early access stage.For now you can enjoy it in multiplayer, as there are manyfeatures like crafting and leveling up your general that I have yet to try my hand on (since I am more into single player mode).8/10

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a very fun little game. The single player is lacking, Needs a proper skirmish mode. Hopefully we get one. Other then that its similar to stronghold crusader, but with fantasy elements similiar to lord of the rings. Are the graphics amazing? no, not really, but its fun and its not taking itself too seriously. I play total war games when i want complete realism on the battlefield. The game is large scale, and i cant stress enough, just fun. You start with a town or whatever from which you build peasents. 1 squad of peasents is like 15 guys. So you build some squads and then you task them out to do things like..work mines for stone, kill pigs for food, loot corpses for gold and stuff, etc etc you get the idea. Each race is different, for example the elves do not chop down trees like humans  do. they are nature lovers or whatever so, they work with the earth.  You build houses to increase population cap. Each house adds 10 squads, each squad can have 15ish men in them. I dont know the max population...i havent hit one yet. But you can see from the video up top on the store page that the battles can be big. Theres upgrades and tech trees, things mostly make sense, like if you have catapults on your wall, they fire stones but in doing so they deplete them from your stock pile. Makes sense to me, Stones arent infinite and free to just toss around.  Theres alot of detail in the maps, The huge cities and towns are really pretty and well thought out. In closing....I dont know how popular this game is, there are clearly more of them, and this is the most recent, but i had never heard of these games before this one. so i cant compare the rest or anything, but man i feel like i stumbled across a little gem. This is true old school rts. Build a barracks get infantry. I compare this most with the lord of the rings rts battle for middle earth. Basically if Battle for middle earth and stronghold had a baby, this would be its offspring. Also reminds me ALOT of warcraft 3 so maybe battle for middle earth cheated with warcraft 3, and stronghold never found out, so stronghold helped raise the kid as his own. LOL

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								As a casual gamer with a larger game collection I don't tend to write reviews for products but this title is very different, What you get is a RTS Strategy game that puts Triple A games like Total Wars to shame that on the face of it doesn't look particulary spectacular but the game play is amazing (note I'm not a kid looking for some pew pew - as a older game mid 30's I like to relax after work for a few hours).Let me get this out of the way straight away:Cons -Can't Move the castle - its been my only gripe so far when you start a battle your castle walls are in a pre defined location (one at each side of the map)Graphics - the textures look like AoE games or games dated around that genre (not a bad thing but the younger gamers wont like it for a 2016 game)From what I've seen (others I read have graphics issues) I've had 100+ units in battle and yes the framerate has dropped but the game has never dipped more then a gig of memory use - (It did make me wonder if this is a 32 bit application)Pro's- Gameplay (the battles keep you returning time and again)- First Battling the AI to get crafting materials (RnG based materials which unlock units to use in battle) - thats right you start with only the most basic of units and castle and work up- Que system - I can't wait to see this with more players you hit your gametype the game seems to auto match the players- No Console - For me not being able to spawn all items in or cheat my way through it is spectacular (the secret room on fallout 4 that gives you everything in the game once you know its there the game is done!)All in all a fantastic game... while I look forward to seeing some progression in its current state its well worth a look (just make sure you stick it out for a few hours) - I've sunk 20 hours in so far in just over a week... i petty my gametime in a month

number of helpful: 22 of 28 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
Product received for free
												I'm not a fan of RTS games, but what the game has to offer is really great! Short Version Well made Progression system, cliche but perfectly fitting races, exciting battles, Freaking Zombies!  usually don't like those, but here they fit great into the game!  rather small dev team, that does a damn amazing job IMHORating 9/10 long Version  Races in KW2:B you can choose between 3 distinct races to fight with: Humans, Orcs and Elves. They might be what you would expect from each race, but that's not really an issue as they made them really well!Humans are pretty basic and medieviel-ish, except they can breed FREAKING DRAGONS! and can train mages, otherwise what you would expect (each race has their heroes, Dwarven "Mercenaries", Mages and Dragons.Orcs - Quantity over Quality - they are really dumb but that makes them fun to play! it's a bit hard getting used to them, as they infinitely spawn at your base (can be toggled) but once you got into it it's relatively easy.Elves - Quality over Quantity - these guys are a bit tricky, as you need to "build" trees in order to build Buildings on it, but they have some neat advantages like a wood gathering spirit. Progression Each race can unlock new buildings, Units, Abilities etc..... (permanently with materials - will cover later) and for each upgrade you make you can see your tribe grow in the main menu, which is a neat feature, although i haven't recognized much difference on single upgrades - but are clearly noticeable when doing more.Once your done upgrading, you can buy Battle cards to aid you in your fights. Cards range from Resources, to units and even timed bonuses.Materials for crafting these Upgrades or Cards can be gathered by completing matches (win or lose) beating every 3 waves in survival, trading or simply by logging in each day - which is IMO a great idea to keep people interested in the game. Game Modes KW2:B has a few game modes BUT keeps growing! currently has 5 game modes:- Capture town flag: Get your Army through the Enemy gates and capture the Town center to beat them.- Total Annihilation: Destroy and murder everything from that player to beat them.- Capture the flag: there is a flag in the middle of the map, you know the drill!-Casualties of War: just murder as many Enemies as possible to win - has a set limit to win- Zombie Survival: like capture town flag, except you have to defend it agains masses of incoming Zombies! pretty hard especially with humans as you can't really get to stone and gold with them. Battles Battles start relatively fast in KW2:B and can be really exciting and pretty frustrating if you just wanna take things easy. But once you got everything set and rush into **** with your team it's a whole lot of fun! But Beware! Killed people can TURN!! so, if you just leave the corpses around they could suddenly stand up and start clawing at you! ways to deal with that fu***rs is by burning them (dead or living.....again) or by tasking your workers to scavenge the corpses.It can especially be fun to let a few peasants die near the enemy camp just to see them turn! >:) Multiplayer Haven't gone into this (cause i think i'm to bad for this :P) but it has PvP and PvE. You can also do a Zombie Survival run with a Friend! Dev Team I usually be veeeery careful on who to call a good dev, but those very few guys working on making the Game great are really amazing! the Game tend to have some issues and when this arises the devs jump on this and try their damn hardest fixing them. They are also really well present in the Forums and are up for new things and suggestions.Overall a great RTS Game that WILL grow much better, I'm sure of it!My Rating 9/10

Posted: November 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								*Starts first game on normal difficulty*-Starts gathering resources-builds two layers of wooden palisade-makes some Archers to defend the outer walls*10-15 minutes in*-Enemy AI sends an onslaught of orcs and battering rams at my walls-Finally finishes them off after a 10 minute battle *Moaning starts* -Zombies completely destroy the gates of my outer walls-Rush to build stone walls while some of my lucky soldiers are able to retreat behind other layer of walls while the rest are trapped, being destroyed by the undead horde-My archers begin to fire at the zombies from my newly created stone walls while the orcs decide to send some wargs which kill the last of the zombies after a few minutes, my archers kill the last 2 wargs-I begin repairing and raising an army-I eventually get to the Orcish base to see that they have glitched and have a massive army doing nothing-After about 2 hours of sending wave after wave of macemen (because I haven't unlocked any good troops) the enemy base is almost destroyed but they continue building more and more units*Game crashes*Pros:-Fun gameplay-The battles don't feel too grindy about resources -Zombies rising adds new strategies no other RTS has-3 Completely distinct race(not complaining about crashing and glitches, because this is early access)Cons:-Enemy computer doesn't have resources.... seriously-AI needs to be worked on, even without the glitch, that they don't attack, all they really did was immediately send troops to attack, I recommend adding different kinds of AI in the battle creating menu [eg. Aggressive, Defensive, Random, Normal (semi-aggressive, semi-defensive)]Conclusion: A great game for early access, I love RTS' like this. Crashing and glitches that need to be worked on a bit, some optimization. PLEASE MAKE COMPUTER AI HAVE TO USE/GATHER RESOURCES, I understand that the AI may need to be better before this is done but just please do not leave it like this for the future. Overall a great game so far, don't expect a shining piece of art but if you like RTS and/or Fantasy games I HIGHLY recommend this early access title.Edit 1: One more recommendation, as far as the enemy defending worked, they just seemed to hangout where ever they were recruited, it would be nice if the enemy built stone walls, towers, etc and stationed troops on walls.

Early Access Review
								I am a big RTS fan, and this game is pretty revolutionary when it comes to the zombie mechanic. (You can turn off the zombies if you don't like them.) The game is basically any other Medieval RTS title, but has zombies! You fortify your castle and upgrade units and structures, there's a whole crafting system in this game, which is weird, but kinda cool. For most new players, like myself it took a few games to realize that I had to craft upgrades from the main menu to actually use them in game. But once I figured it out, the game really came to life.Basically how it works: You play campaign/multiplayer/singleplayer vs AI. Once you have played a few games, you will get these special resources, now I don't know how to actually acquire them, but it seems like the more games you play, the more you get. Anyway so once you have these resources you can craft certain upgrades that can be used in game. (For the Humans, Halberdier for example.) And after you craft the upgrade you can use it in game. Pretty cool stuff.All in all this game is pretty awesome. I mean it needs some more refining, and at random times may crash. (Save Often!!!!) It'll get framy and just gucky, so be prepared to have it crash, also sometimes your units won't respond to orders, I've noticed if you stop moving the screen and click it usually works. lol other than that this game is a diamond in the rough, totally worth the money if you wanna support the devs. It's really fun in the state that it's in. Can't wait to see what they do with it in the future! 10/10 Would get sieged by Zombies again.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Product received for free
												Game: Kingdom Wars 2 :BattlesPublisher: Reverie World StudiosStill in Early accessGameplayKingdom Wars 2: Battles is a RTS game set in the medieval era with emphasis on battles of epic proportions and managing your kingdom. At first glance, it is a typical run of the mill RTS game which provides players with 3 races : Humans, Orcs and Elves. All the races here are pretty well balanced and none of them feel overpowered in any way. Then there are the undead which spawn when blood has been shed on the battlefield and they have the potential to destroy the army which was remaining on the battlefield. The other part of the gameplay consists of villagers/orcs who build buildings to keep you in control of the battlefield.  There is variation present in the type of soldiers you can build to keep things fresh. You can also upgrade various abilities to make your army better. The gameplay here is fairly basic for RTS otherwise with little to no surprises. Though it does execute the basic things pretty well and is very much enjoyable inspite of the clichéd RTS tropes.Visuals Kingdom wars 2 isn’t the best looking RTS out there. It falls somewhere in the lower end spectrum in the graphics category. It reminds me of Lord of the Rings: Battle for Middle Earth II which was a pretty good looking game of it’s time. The water in Kingdom wars 2 is spot on. You can see the waves rushing towards the shore as you make your way through the game. The unit models have some variation but are not as well made as they should have been. Some buildings have some very good design but most of them feel very much rushed out. You can see the buildings, especially the gates being upgraded not only through stats but also visually which brings a really good feeling. Overall, the graphics here are fairly average and nothing exceptional or bad is found here.SoundThe music in Kingdom wars 2 is really good. It really escalates the feeling of a battle and amps up the sound as the mood changes from peaceful to a more violent nature. The sounds from your units and villagers though interesting at first gets repetitive in not more than 4-5 hours, which is common in most RTS games so it is nothing big of a deal. The battle cries of your soldiers and the grunts of the zombies are good enough to keep you invested in the battle raging in front of you. The music and sound in Kingdom wars 2 is pretty neat to say the least.Current performanceKingdom Wars 2 features an episodic single player campaign which is fairly long as of now. The tutorial is actually one of the best tutorials you will find in a RTS games. It is fairly complicated but explains most of the situations to you. I did not find bugs in single player except a couple of freezes and some minor annoyances. The multiplayer though is somewhat of an issue. It did not take me long to connect to a multiplayer game but the lag in the middle of the games were annoying to unbearable. The multiplayer needs to be worked on as it is not in the best condition. Bugs are plentiful too when playing multiplayer ranging from some sound cuts to major lag and crashing of the game. It runs pretty well though when playing an offline game. Since it is still in early access, we should expect to see much more bugs being ironed out.Overall reviewKingdom Wars 2:Battles is a game which is really enjoyable by the fans of the genre. It’s massive battles and the inclusion of undead really gives a pleasurable experience. The single player campaign is fairly long and there are a lot of options to mess around in a random game. The multiplayer needs some work and there are quite a lot of bugs. It won’t change the mind of the people who don’t enjoy the genre but there are a lot of redeeming qualities which make this a great game. Rating 7/10This review is brought to you by Steamified. For similar reviews and fantastic giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												If you’re looking for a game that genuinely feels increasingly rewarding the longer than you play it then I urge you to try Reverie World Studios Kingdom Wars 2: Battles that has been recently released out of Steam Early Access.Although the game was bundled twice during its Early Access period, meaning many of you may already own the game and therefore have an even greater reason to play it now, the game is definitely worth its asking price especially for those of you who have the time and the energy to make the effort to playing this through to completion. Although I’ve spent four hours playing the game I can already foreshadow that this is the type of game that you could easily sink hundreds of hours in. There are five full campaigns and that’s without even considering the multiplayer. As of writing there are well over one hundred players playing and the in game chat system was vibrant and active so finding a match shouldn’t be a problem for some time.One of the best things about the game is that there are three playable races. However, unlike a number of other games where each race feels very much alike even though units and buildings may be given different names the play styles of each race feel very different from one another. If not for the graphics then at times you would have a hard time believing that you were playing the same game which is a real boon for a genre where variety can be an important selling point. Another strength of the three race system in this game is that – at least in my experience – none of the races play over or underpowered when compared to the other. Certainly there may be a race that plays to your own individual strengths or against your weaknesses but it is a game where putting in the time to learn to master one or more will give you an advantage in the multiplayer.There are some weaknesses to the game. My biggest one would be the graphics. The UI, because of the graphics, needs a fair amount of work but I’m not entirely certain as to how I would go to polish it but I do know that it needs work from its present state. At times the screen can be too busy and I found it difficult in these times to know which units – peasants – weren’t being busy. This is especially apparent on the tutorial level where there are just so many different units that bombard you that you can lose track of what is happening all too quickly. I know that I wasn’t the first player to lose at the tutorial level and have this complaint. There are also some bugs that continue to remain in the game. However, to be very fair to the developers, they’ve been great and are removing them from the game at a rapid pace and this has been the case throughout the entirety of the development process.However, the tutorial level – even if you include the fact that there is a little bit too much going on – is one of the better ones that I’ve played. It’s a welcome introduction to the challenge that you will be experiencing throughout the game. This isn’t a walk in the park regardless of the level of difficulty that you play on and that is as it should be. Some players may well be frustrated at just how tough the challenge can be but if you’re wanting an engaging and challenging game in this genre then you’ve found it.My favorite aspect of the game is the fantastic skirmish gameplay. This is genuinely the type of game that I would recommend to those who loved the original Warcraft games as well as those of you who play Rise of Nations and other similar games. You’ll be surprised at just how much depth there is to your city/base building while also at the same time how strategically you must be in designing the type of armies that will enable you to be successful. Players of both types of games will be at a distinct advantage as you utilize a combination of the skills throughout the campaign and multiplayer modes.There is a ton to like about Kingdom Wars 2: Battles. There is potential for the title to become even better. The devs have been great and if they continue working on the title then it could become a classic. If you already own the game thanks to the Damnation Bundle from Bundle Stars or the Be Mine 21 bundle from Groupees then get on board and play it. If not and you’re a fan of the game then you really owe it to yourself to check it out if not right away then when it goes on sale.For our popular daily giveaways and similar reviews head over to http://www.steamified.com/To begin your journey through our myriad of social media join our Steam Group

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								The peasants finally finish the last section of stone wall surrounding our village when the Elven scum strike. Huge tree men advance at the front of their lines, finally reaching my gates and kicking with their oak-tree like legs. "FIRE", screams the captain of the archer squads, as they let loose an unholy barrage of arrows at the pointy-eared hellspawn. Elven warriors try to advance onto the walls when macemen stationed on high tip cauldrons full of boiling oil down on their evil little heads. A loud crash is heard from the rear of the keep. "My Lord, they have destroyed the rear gate!". " TO ARMS", I scream, as I lead my men on a thunderous charge into the enemy ranks. What feels like decades later, the battle ends. Scores of bodies, both human and elf, lay mangled on the ground.     Suddenly, moaning sounds start blasting from my pc speakers. What the? The mangles corpses start rising from the dead, and now I'm fighting...zombies?      A pretty cool game that reeks of potential. Have only played single player skirmish so far but I like what I see. Maps, units, upgades are all interesting. Had a few CTD's so I'm hoping for a little polish over the next few months. A solid offering so far.

Early Access Review
								Ok, this game is interesting. The Graphics are meh, but the game is really easy to learn. The game has you start off gathering resources and training an army. After that the game turns into wolf killing simulator 2015 for a little while. Once you have your army ready for battle and your peasants working... then you are ready for battle! Battle consists of:-Killing enemies-Killing houses-Killing enemy soldiers-Killing your own men who turn into zombies-Watching your own men get killed by wolves that they passed bySo in all the game is definitely in alpha, but for $15 it has a great deal of potential.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
Early Access Review
Kingdom Wars 2: Battles ReviewKingdom Wars 2: Battles (which I will refer to as KW2B in this review) is a bold approach to RTS strategic simulation games that focuses on the building and destroying of massive medieval citadels. The battles are intense and the strategy is unlike most other simulations out there so most players can expect a challenging experience unlike any they have faced before. That is, unless you happened to play the original Kingdom Wars. What gives this series its unique flavor is Reverie World Studios, INC's strong focus on siege warfare, making it unlike anything else being developed.Players will naturally need to gather resources, build structures, research technologies, and train armies just like in most other RTS sims of this nature. However, the economy and techs have all been streamlined so the player doesn't have to micro-manage their progression and can devote most of their attention to the battles themselves. Currently there are three races to choose from: Humans, Elves, and Orcs. Each race has its own unique units, structures and styles. Since the game is still Early Access, its possible that more will be added later but I cannot say for certain.Players can choose between single-player story mode played out in episodes, skirmish mode, and Multiplayer mode. There is only one episode available now but current plans include five in total and these additional episodes will be released as Free DLC's. Other features in the works include a crafting system based on rewards earned during battles for a variety of advancements, an intricate card system used for powerful bonuses during games, a trading market where players can trade crafting items with other players, and a guild system that will allow players to create or join a battle clan for shared strength. At this time, some of these things are still in development so its not easy to elaborate on them, but they sound pretty cool.The graphics are very rich but older systems struggle to keep up on moderately high settings so this may change in order to accommodate more players, especially for Multiplayer PvP. There is an in-game chat system so players can communicate during gameplay without the hassles of using the Steam overlay. A level editor is included for the mod community can get a jumpstart on their own creations. The sound effects are a bit troublesome currently and being sorted out. Nothing new for an Alpha version though. Also, there are still a number of bugs scattered about so don't be alarmed. This is typical of an Early Access game and the devs welcome any information on them so they can work to correct the problems. Still, the game is very stable and entertaining. Being part of the Early Access phase gives players the opportunity to help shape the future of KW2B and help the developers build the best game possible. However, if you're one of those gamers who has little patience or prefers only finished/polished projects, then i suggest holding off a while longer. Unhappy gamers do nothing to help the community, the developers, or the game.The Good:=======+  Solid graphics and detailed artwork+  Three fully unique races+  Various player modes for added replay value+  Crafting and Card systems for player bonuses+  Fully rotating camera with smooth controls+  In-game chat system+  Steam Achievements & Trading Cards+  Level Editor included for the Workshop+  Active & friendly game devs+  Free DLC's +  More cool features being addedThe Bad:======-  Still has a lot of bugs to be worked out (typical for Early Access)-  Audio is a mess right now-  User Interface and layout still needs some work-  Many features and elements are missing (still under development)-  Graphics are a strain on older systemsFinal Thoughts:===========KW2B has all the promise of a great game and I have no doubt the developers will see this game all the way through to a polished gem. Siege warfare is often a neglected aspect of RTS strategy sims and its rarely done properly so this game offers a fresh experience for most players. Strategy players will definitely want to grab a copy and strap in for battle. This game isn't the best choice for impatient people or those who expect to have a smooth and complete experience since its still Early Access Alpha though.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Hello All, (Final Beta Release)Id like to start out by saying that I love this game but, my girlfriend hates it. In the weekend following its purchase iv logged just under 30h. I played abit of the campaign, Multiplayer, Survival and skirmish. Out of all the modes Survival is my favorite.PROS- The amount of Units one can sustain on the battlefield rivals TA (Total Annihliation) and TW (All Total Wars)- The combat mechanics, Siege mechanics are fantastic- 3 Unique races all with their own spin- THE SCALE!- The Maps (though id like more)- The graphics are slightly above average but leave lots to be desired- Army customization via personnel armors, weapon upgrades and health/Regen ect ect.- Seperate tech tree for each faction- Unique card system for enhanced starts- Guilds/friends list/trading system- Low PC demands given the sheer scale- Trial by fireCONS (most being adressed ASAP)- Poor unit pathing Warriors and Peasents alike (especially for wood)- Alot of missing content for a Final Beta release- AI even on easy starts with near infinite resources forcing a turtle everytime (very hard)- Exploitable Race mechanic (The orcs are the only ones i know of)- HUD lacking important info- Unit huds lacking important info- Bugs and crashes (not unplayable at all)- Only one way to build a fortress for each faction (could use different keep and fortress layouts, dont confuse this with building stuff, this only affects where walls can be built)- Lacking a real tutorial besides the campaign, especially for combat/ damage types- Zombie glitches/bugsCONCLUSIONBuilt an army to lend AID to my survival partner. My army and his die defending his lands, soldiers killed by zombies rise. Rapes my lands and decimates my people to extinction. Cows and sheep last to die off. 11/10 WPA&A&A&A

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Kingdom Wars 2: Battles:~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~   A kingdom without a king is a recipe for war! Three races are engaged in this devastating conflict and trying to survive. Who is going to have the upper hand? Would it be the Orcs, possibly the Elves or it just might be the Humans?!Kingdom War 2: Battles is an RTS game which offers several modes of play. In the campaign mode, you will be playing four episodes at this stage (the fifth episode is coming soon), you will be treated with very good cinematics as well as an in-depth story line. This episode with be all about the last stronghold for the human race, the city of “Dagbor.” You will be playing the Humans and then the Orcs. During the gameplay, you will have to achieve all tasks before entering a battle. Essentially, it is like a very good tutorial. You will learn how to gather resources, create buildings and units. The single player mode is realistically a skirmish; choose your race and up to three others players (AI) to fight against. In the survival mode, you will be fighting against waves of zombies. There is quite a lot of content here. There is a technology tree for the 3 races and you can unlock upgrade with different resources. If you are missing some, head up to the trade centre and buy what you need from another user. By clicking on the social icon, you will be able to see who is online, become a friend with whoever you want, challenge or engage in a co-op game.Strategic cards can be crafted and used in a multiplayer game. Select a combination of cards to have the edge against your opponent but be aware, they might have a better combination than you.The gameplay is good, as are the graphics, although I did experience a couple of flicking screen effects here and there. The controls are easy to master and follow the trend of this type of game. The only negative here is that I had to click several times to the same points for my units to acknowledge my command, and this can be frustrating.Positives:~~~~~~~~    -	Good graphics-	Good story and cinematics -	3 races to play with each their specific tech tree-	Achievements and Trading cardsNegatives:~~~~~~~~ -	Controls could be more responsiveI really like RTS and Kingdom War 2: Battles show great potential. 7.5/10Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!MORE THE_CPT_FROGGY REVIEWS HEREFOLLOW THE CPT FROGGY CURATOR PAGE HERE

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												Alot of time has gone by since I first made a serious review of this game, so I think, as it has made significant steps in the right direction, I should update my review of it.Kingdom Wars 2 has all the makings of a classic, aswell as a few things that make it definately stand out, some things seem like poor choices... i don't know why there's a progression system in an RTS, or why its next to impossible to get any of the high level crafting objects, but those are just nitpicks, so lets tear into the game as a whole shall we? I'll be judging it as if it was a finished project so anything that ends up being ironed out when you read this may no longer be applicable.The game features the standard 3 factions, a faction with expensive troops, a faction with tankish troops, and a faction with cheap troops, however each faction works in very unique ways such as how they gather their resources and how they build their armies, which is a neat thing to see in an RTS.Kingdom wars 2 is also the first RTS I've seen to feature zombification as a mechanic, and its more or less clunky, it really just makes sieges more of a hassle and slows the game down, but it has its high moments, there's a lot tension when a massive army of your troops or an enemy's army has been defeated near something important, and you need to clear the area of corpses before either: your enemy arrives again or the sun sets.The strategy side of this game seems fairly weak, sad to say, this hasn't changed at all in the past year, no doubt this is because the community for this game is fairly small, and the armies themselves aren't balanced ESPECIALLY orcs. The people who play this game regularly seem to play it exclusively for the survival mode, which is kinda a shame for me.I'm happy to see the majority of glitchs have been ironed out, and the remaining lag is probably just the fault of my own computer or internet, i'm not sure.This game is still not finished, though it is finally ready for release, I suppose. The units are grossly unbalanced, but and the devs do seem very invested in the community around this game, so I'm actually going to go ahead and recommend you support them still.

content:
Posted: January 9
The conceptKW2B is a (partially asymmetric) RTS. It is NOT your typical Starcraft/ competitive melee RTS clone but rather the "enjoy your units and have some fun" kind.You build your base, gather 4 types of resources, research upgrades and recruit your army. On top, you get to fortify your base with several layers of upgradeable walls so attacking an enemy always ends in a siege battle. There are 3 different races with ample differences in gameplay and base building and each of them gets their own castle.And at this point you're probably asking yourself: "Wait, I can't build my own castle or what?". The answer is YES. The castle layout is fixed and so is the general landscape beneath your base. You can place your RTS typical structures wherever you want but wall segments, gates and towers are all built on a fixed "addon" location. However, this doesn't detract from the fun and I'll explain why down below.As for game modes, it offers a singleplayer campaign which also acts as tutorial, PVP up to 4 players, COOP vs AI (the AI is good enough) and a zombie survival wave mode where you defend your castle (and that of your friends) against ever increasing waves of zombies.What you're getting yourself intoThis is a low-budged indie game with all the pros and cons:Be prepared for a truck load of bugs.  The game has anything from crashes and disfunctional addons over a laggy interface which also is not always properly updated to minor bugs which can be summed up as 'lack of polishing'.The devs are actively involved with the community and do their best. This has to be pointed out as well. You can find developers in the ingame chat every day and they do their best to respond and act on every bug report you commit. They also mediate in balance discussions and admit if something has been overnerfed or whatever. In general it's a very pleasent experience with these devs and they put out patches on a regular basis.Moderators are online almost around the clock and the entire community is small but very helpful.What makes this game special?Well maybe special is the wrong word. KW2B employs a large variety of iconic game mechanics from other RTS (many of which are lost today) and mixes them. The result is compelling to me because a) I get to enjoy all those mechanics again and b) it is simply fun to play.I'll try to give you an idea (RTS veterans will understand):Resources work exactly like in age of empiresThere is food, gold, wood and stone. You start with high gathering rate but limited resource patches to kickstart your base and then transition into slower but renewable resource generation for late game. How and what exactly depends on your race. Generally speaking, elves have the most stable renewable resource generators, humans the most efficient and orcs spawn free units instead.Meta tech trees for every race (like AoE online)For every player you kill, for every game you win and for every day you log in you get a loot reward. There is a good dozen of items with varying rarity to be gathered and you use those to permanently unlock new structures, units and upgrades for your race to be used in any future match.Once you've unlocked them all, you can spend those resources on "cards" which are one time boosters you can bring into the next match. For example, you can spawn a blob of additional, free workers or add a ton of food to your bank.Soft rock-paper-scissors balance Like in many strategy games you have units which are specialized in killing a specific unit type. However, it's not dead set in this balance. You can still damage cavalry with archers and swordmen for example, but you trade units with less efficiency. Your fortress, good micro or a better economy can easily offset this, though.Unit verterancy and stat pointsAs you upgrade your barracks it will train units of higher level. Killing enemy units will grant them additional exp. Unlike the usual veterance system though, it's up to the player to decide which stats are improved on a level up. A leveled unit basically gains stat points like in an RPG that you can apply to one of it's 3 defenses, damage, movement speed, health, stamina (which is also used as mana), etc.Hero units and WizardsEvery race has a bunch of heroes and wizards like in Battle for Middle earth 2. You can train and level them like regular units but they have a higher max level and a whole lot of active abilities. There are also war beasts and mercenary units!Captureables and neutral fortifications across the mapConsidering you have everything at home you need (more or less) there is little reason to leave the save embrace of your fort right? Wrong! The maps are littered with capturable pieces like bandit forts, lumber mills, quarries (which provide you additional renewable income) and ruins of old castles which walls and towers you can man like they're your own. These ruins offer choke points, ambush routes and everything the heart of a tactician requires. And then there is a dragon on every map, guarding a treasure (additional meta loot) which the players compete for.Fortifications So let me get back to what I said in the beginning. You can man your walls with archers and other units and mount ballistas, trebuchets, oil and a bunch of other machines onto towers and gates like in Stronghold. Unlike stronghold the final layout of your walls, towers and gates is fixed rather than pieced together by the player. Tbh, the layout of the landscape and your base greatly differs depending on which race you play. The concept here is comparable to Empire at War or Battle for Middle Earth 1.Also unlike Stronghold the devs had the opportunity to carfully craft and balance your foritifcations so the result is more complex and fun than anything you can build with the limited tools in that so called castle simulator (SH). You get access to walls of different heights, you have up to 3 layers of fully seperated, fully mannable (if upgraded) walls. Your keep is always located on a hill which gives you further height and line of sight advantage (both matter for archers) and there is always a backdoor.Additionally, you're not forced to fully upgrade your defenses every game. Sometimes you want to leave the out wall a mere fence to slow down the enemy an keep your forces together at the base's core. Sometimes you want the out wall asap to better control the area around your base. Thus your castle doesn't necessarily look the same every game.Zombies!As an additional source of income you can task your workers to loot the corpses on the battlefield. Yes, the insane gore in this game is part of the gameplay! Even better, not looting them before nightfall means they will rise as zombies which pose a serious threat. The zombies don't fight for any player per se but a good player will know how to use them to their advantage...ConclusionThis game may fall flat on you if you have too high expectations. It's not super polished and the graphics aren't really up to date. That said, the music, art design and concept are just beatiful and super enjoyable. KW2B can stand on it's own and fill a niche that other RTS have left wide open for the past years.If that is what you are looking for the stop reading and buy the game already!

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Tons of bugs:1. If your peasents are harvesting a tree near a cliff edge, they will often times forsake the tree next to it and climb all the way down the mountain to harvest the tree down the cliff that is closer horizontally.2. Dragon animation is choppy and poor. When it flies over a wall it sort of warp lands on the other side. It also shoots fireballs out the back of its head when you target a location behind where it is looking. 3. The graphics are fairly poor compared to other rts games of this time and genre.4. The peasant animations are also choppy and the cycling for the chopping animation on trees does not transiition smoothly resulting in them rapidly raising the axe two times in a row.5. I got the dragon slayer achievement just by letting the enemy ai take out the dragon and I looted the dragon treasure afterwards.6. The boulders from the trebs tend to explode in mid air above their targets at times.7. The level of castle customization only accounts for placing buildings, you can't choose where to build your walls and you can't place indipendant towers so establishing a defensive position is only possible with units and possibly occupying ai creep camps.8. Sometimes only a few units in a group attack the enemy, letting potential increase battle effectiveness slip by since the rest of the group just sits back for 5 seconds waiting to join the battle.9. The map variety is zip for single player. They are the same sections of land repasted in different patterns. Not much variety from the original F2P version of Kingdom Wars. (not a bug)10. The enemy ai likes to sit outside your gate while you slaughter them with arrows because they forgot to bring siege equipment with them.11. Also not really a bug, but I don't find it really feasible for zombies that are already loose conglamerations of flesh and guts to be able to tear down solid stone walls.12. Peasant ai sux.13. Peasants don't finish off a tree before they go ADD and decide to go look for another tree to chop down. (unless the decay animation is really slow and hangs around for a while after the tree has been exhausted, but I wouldn't know since there is no indicator as to how much wood is left in a tree)14. Not a bug, but you cant have multiple save games of single player battles/skirmishes. Makes me frustrated that I cant save at any point in the campaign missions.15. If you save during the zombie horde survival single player mode, and let yourself die then you can quit the game after you get the reward and continue again and repeat and get a lot of crafting mats. At least that happened to me after I got to wave 7. (I only exploited this glitch three of four times).14. ECT.Overall, I love the concept and idea, just poorly implemented. To be honest, I would reccomend The Lord of The Rings Battle for Middle Earth 2 over this any time. Therefore, I do not reccomend this game until they fix and polish the mechanics of this game. Sorry for the grammer mistakes, but I don't feel like fixing them.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
Notification: I got a free copy of the game for review purposes.This review only mirrors my expressions from an early development version - It is not up to date! Summary Kingdom Wars 2: Battles is a medieval styled strategy game with a affection to card games and massive battles. You get the chance to control your own empire of orcs, elves or humans in a war shattered world with with their very own play style and build-up system.Playing each single race feels totally different to the other ones and the player needs to choose wisely between them and their belonging cards to match their own type of tactics.Pro'sUnique play style with different races and card decksLess micromanagement due to squads of unitsPossibility to fight relatively huge battlesBased on old school games like Starcraft, Warcraft and AoEFast update and development progressStable gameplay despite being early accessLevel-up system based on cardsCon'sGraphics are still partly early stageRather bad pathfinding (soon to change)Battles seem pretty buggy at this point - Most arrows can't hit their target properly and units behave pretty dumb at some pointsMy own ConclusionWhen playing this game for the first time I felt like being reminded of my first gaming adventures with those good old strategy classics like Age of Empires or Warcraft 2 - this game got a big potential of becoming the next attempt to revive the dying art of building strategy games. Also the first few campaign missions gave a nice introduction to the future of this game.There is indeed only one thing I can really complain about at this very moment: The game is still unfinished - that needs to be changed ASAP.Imaginary Rating: 8.2/10

number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												This is a game that at face value looks rough around the edges. Being an RTS/Stategy/Simulation-ish game, it fills a very niche market, one which I always struggle to find the right game for me, that satisfies my every need - decent castle building, solid warfare, economy / resource gathering and units gaining veternacy with progression, and I can gladly say that this game fulfills my every need. I would highly reccomend this game to anyone who is a fan of age of empires and especially stronghold. The graphics aren't the best - but after an hour you get used to it, what matters more is core gameplay (look at games like terraria and minecraft as an example). Suddenly you have this nostalgia of old games with modern mechanics and it really is fantastic.One of my favourite features - zombie survival in an RTS! You have a castle like a normal game but you're tasked with surviving wave after wave and this can be done cooperatively! After every 3rd wave you unlike crafting materials that you can use after the battle to craft the various cards and race upgrades.This is just a taste of what the game offers and I have barely scratched the surface my self, but with such helpful and ACTIVE dev team members in game chat (which is visible throughout all games and menus) I felt compelled to write my first review of a game in a long time. Buy it, support the produces and watch this fantastic game grow - there's a lot to offer and the team have an amazing philosophy, something we cannot say for most modern games these days.

Early Access Review
								If you are a Kingdom Wars fan or hell, even an Old School RTS fan i strongly recommend to try this out. First, I Alpha tested this game and i am proud to say the developers are very responsive to bugs and happily accept suggestons from all usersSecondly, this game (so far as its in beta now) Irons out most of the bugs on Kingdom Wars 1 and other RPG's such as the "Out of Sync" issue with multiplayer games such as this. The old school economy system also brings back nostalgia from older RTS's namly Age of Empires. Thirdly,  The Community. The community is made up of a lot of old school players who could relate to old times and also are friendly with new players. Anyway if your a fan of RTS's or maybe even just like RTS's than this is definitley a good choice to try out with responsive devs, nostalgic economy system and general gameplay, and great community willing to help out!

								Still early access game but man its looking good deff cant wait to see how it ends up, its like the total war games, and a hint of stronghold but better way better. content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												Where do I start.. Ah yes. KW2B has honestly astounded me, for being a new release it is very well done and the Dev's are on point with support and patches. The gameplay merges with the large openness of the game quite beautifully. The massive armies of siegeness to the simple raids of infantry, it also comes together nicely and keeps you on your toes. The complexity of managing an attack force, a defense and your economy puts players at their best. Combine that with the possibility of "Oh No!" of a zombie attack for not cleaning the army you have just successfully wiped out makes it a challenge. The races are well done, all balanced to eachother and the tech trees giving you an edge over your opponent make it wonderful to build your own strategies. The campaign is so well in depth and fun to play, the problem is waiting for the next Act/Chapter, whatever you feel the need to call it. I'm very pleased with this game and it was well worth the buy, I highly reccomend it to anybody wanting a well-paced RTS.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Feels very sloppy, which could be as a result of it being based off the back of a FTP MMO. When you tell units to move often the flag doesn't appear at their chosen location, and if you select a group to move it's pure guesswork where they'll end up. Upgrading troops is a pain because there is no noticable indicator they're ready for upgrade unless you click on them individually, additionally once you've upgraded one unit type (i.e. archers) the UI bugs out for all subsequent upgrades.The graphics are poor, and there are several anomolies including blue and white screen flashes.Presumably as it used to be a FTP MMO there is no save option in the single player campaign, you have to wait for checkpoints which can be hours apart. I tested the checkpoint save system by waiting till a checkpoint and exiting, and on reloading it had lost 40 minutes progress, it was at this point I decided it was time for a refund.

content:
