												What can I say....THIS IS AN EXCEPTIONAL GAME!!!   So fun, very challenging. Lots of moving parts and some very deep systems at play here. If you like castle building, real strategy, age of empires, stronghold kind of RTS you will go absolutely nuts for this title.  1000's of units on screen duking it out with blood everywhere. (Makes sure you clean up the bodies by the way or now you have an army of the dead attacking you). 3 different playable races currently that each have their own completely unique attributes, units and economic system. Resouce gatherin is fun and also challenging.I have been waiting for a game like this for a long time. For the price it's a steal. Can't say enough good things. Start off wtih the Campaign. Fun to play through and great way to sample all the playable races, that you get some stuff for unlocks in the global skill tree's and bonus cards you use for the single player and multiplayer part of the game. Yes skill trees!

Early Access Review
								Great game.I consider it to be the future successor to Stronghold and Castle Strike.The zombie mechanics are also execllent and add another layer of challenge to the game,reminding me of the tv series The Walking Dead,except this time,it is in medieval ages with medieval weapons.Any corpse (friendly/enemy) not looted/burned in five mins will have a  chance to turn into a zombie,higher if of a more expensive type of unit.A lot of corpses outside your stronghold=potential zombie apocalypse.The zombies are slow,but strong and difficult to kill.Best chance is fire arrows.The only problem is the lack of polish and bugfixing,especially unit to unit combat and ai,hopefully will be updated and fixed in future patches.Or you could wait for its full release.For now as it stands, 8/10.

												I have only been playing this game for a few hours and I'm completely in love with it. I haven't played an RTS game in years, which was Halo Wars (if that even counts as an RTS game, I'm not sure), but I'm loving the gameplay and artwork. Not to mention, the developers are also totally in contact with the community. I oppened up the game after downloading it and the first thing I see is the global chat and the Devs talking to the players. In my opinion, that is one of the BEST features. There are also many other game modes such as Zombie Survival, PVP, and PVE. However, new players will want to start with the campaign since it teaches the basics of the game. If you have any questions (as I did), just ask the amazing community of the game in the chat. I strongly recomend this game, even though I've only played a few hours, because of the great community, caring developers, and amazing gameplay.

Early Access Review
								I love this game. It is an incredibly RTS game, kind of reminds me of Battle for Middle-earth 2 and Age of Empires... With Zombies. But it still has issues. The controls aren't very responsive (I play a lot of Starcraft 2, and that one is very very responsive). Sometimes I have to click 2 or 3 times in order to move a unit and there is no attack-move function (or if there is, I don't know how it works). And then there is the biggest problem I have ever faced with an RTS game: SYNCRONISATION! I've played with a friend a couple of times, and the game was never in sync. He was doing something I didn't see, so that wasn't happening on my screen. He told me he was at my base but I couldn't see it, and the other way around. I seriously hope that gets fixed, because it is a big turn-off.But all in all this is a great RTS game :D

												Very pleasant and deep but unpolished Rts.3 different factions (Orcs,Elves,Humans) with different playstyles with a gameplay that i would describe as a mix of stronghold (but no free castle building) and battle for Middle Earth with a zombie Kicker. content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												This game is an amazing RTS!Cons:The graphics are a few years outdated, but for me this isnt a big problem becuase I love games like Warcraft and Warcraft 3aswell as the orginal starcraft series, this game reminds me of Battle for Middle Earth (the first one).Multiplayer kinda sucks, my freind and I have been playing this game for about a week now and we have been dicconected ingame and it doesnt stop the game but instead the AI takes over and we then technicly start playing a single player battle.Sadly there is no custmizable banners and colors so you are stuck with default.AI, the AI in this game SUCKS! the workers are really, and I mean really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. the soldiers AI when I tell them to hold their ground charge out to meet the enemy dooming my entire defence! and dont even get me started on zombie AI (the AI for players in zombie/survival mode)BUGS! there are a ton of glitches and bugs so watch out for those when you are playing this.Framrates are horrendous and will drop anytime I get into a multiplayer game, AND I have a beefy computer, I am able to run (smoothly at high graphics) Rome Total War. (and Rome Total war has a very bad engine and I can run it fine in large scale batles) But in this game whenever I build more than 5 units the game starts dropping frames.AND NOW! unto the Pros:This game is so much fun! I want to play this more then I do right now (but for certain problems with the game I cant) one thing I love the most about this game is that there is a Zombie mode (survival mode). But with the Zombie/Survival mode comes a WHOLE BUNCH! Of problem that I am not going to include in this. for the most part the game runs fine and the battle are amazing, I love the way that the seiges take place, team Green sets up his massive force to assualt team Yellow and then all of a sudden team Purple swoops in from behind and starts attacking team Green, Green team then calls for the aid of their temporary allies the Brown team to aid them in this massive battle taking place over at the Purple Teams city. this happened to me and it was amazing to see this battle play out (even though I was Yellow, I was seiged and defending for the most part) in the end Yellow team pushed Purple, Green AND Brown out of his city and then procededs to seige and defeat Brown and Purple teams, just before Yellow team gets seiged again by team Green! (in the end I lost, I ddint have enough recourses becuase they were all gone and my market would not give me any gold for all the meat I was trying to give it, so in the end I lost becuase I could not defend my walls)Overall this game in its current state is a 7/10maybe in the future it can go beyond that but for not it doesnt seem like it, and also if they do not fix the bugs and quirks happening throught this, my rating for this game would drop to a 4/10. (love the game but the problems are huge and need to be fixed)

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game shows a lot of promise but unfortunately suffers from the same bugs that were present in the first one.  The music, for example, constantly resets itself to the default setting after it loops forcing you to go into the options menu every few minutes to turn it down/off.  While there is a single player campaign, there is no save feature at present.  This is unfortunate, considering that the game crashed after 20 minutes of playing the first level with no way to recover it.  I like the ideas it brings to the table: craft-able cards, researching permanent tech upgrades...sort of reminds me of "Age of Empires Online" that way.  The developers have also proven through their first game that they have no problem with releasing free DLC/add-ons and responding to the community.  To that end, I'd say pick this up if you don't mind the bugs (buildings disappearing, etc.) and lack of a save feature...otherwise, wait a while until the game becomes a bit more polished.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												(I bought this game on sale, so keep that in mind when reading) The graphical style of this game is its lowest feature, but if you can get past it or it doesnt matter to you then youll find a fun, albeit imperfect game. Kingdom wars 2 is an RTS in the classic style with some intresting intricacies and improvements on the overall formula. There are a few main recources: food, gold, wood, stone, and population. Where the game shines in my opinion is the differeing abilities to gather these recources. For instance, after a battle you can task peasants to loot corpses for gold and valuable loot, and as they do so they will also make sure the soldiers that died dont come back from the dead. Which brings me to arguably the most fun part of this game, the zombies. The zombies are a dynamic RTS threat that I have not seen done anywhere else and they are enough to pick this game up if you see it on sale.When fighting the zombies you have to take a completely different approach to combat. If you send waves after waves of enemies to get chopped up by them youll only make the situation worse, because those freshly dead corpses will rise up from the grave to haunt you. If they get out of hand they can easily overwhelm you and with a combined effort topple your walls and destroy your recources crippling you completely as they overwhelm your stronghold. Being defeated by the zombies is almost fighting them.Keep in mind this review is only for the single player, as I have not tried the multiplayer, but even as a solitary experience I found this game worth a buy at sale cost.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												This is a fairly fresh approach to the RTS genre, it throws in a few things which just make the game so much more enjoyable.It seems to take a few ideas from games such as AOE III, and by that I mean you can use cards during the game for extra resources, a few troops etc, only difference being you will have to craft these cards. You also have to play the game through a bit before fully unlocking all units and benefits within, as you receive materials for finishing matches which can then be used to craft new techs.Gameplay is pretty standard RTS, with a few suprises which keep you on your feet. Your base will fortify itself by upgrades, and (this is one of my favourite things in an RTS) you can position your archers on your walls to defend from invaders. There are scattered benefits around the map, such as extra resource deposits for your workers to mine, gold carts (defended by packs of wolves usually), and small forts (defended by bandits) which are good for strategic positions.The main thing I love about this game, which had me and a friend thoroughly entertained, was that your (and your allies/enemies) troops don't stay dead.. They will rise again as zombies, and at night are even worse to deal with. Essentially, even if you win a fight against your opposition, you'd best get your troops far away from there, or at least hope to god that that fight didn't take place near your base. The zombies swarm, you fight them off with troops and lose more, they gain more zombies, it becomes a losing battle fast.There is also a survival gamemode, in which you (and allies) defend your bases against zombie hordes. It seems like a normal gamemode, except instead of fortresses they have cemeteries spawning zombies at increasing rates every round. It becomes hilarious and terrifying the longer the game goes on.Pros:-Fun gameplay-Great multiplayer-Fun Gamemodes-Interesting advancement with crafting techs for new units-Collecting materials makes tryharding those slow AI matches worthwhileCons:-Not completelty optimised if your PC isn't fantastic, can get very framey at times (the worst during the survival gamemode)-Limited to 3 different teams (races)-A slight lack of unit variety on each time-Limited amount of maps to play on as opposed to randomly generated maps on other RTS'Overall, the only cons of the game are things which can be improved over time and in further development/expansions, and I hear a new expansion (free, might I add) is coming in May. If you're questioning whether the game is worth its price, I highly recommend it. You'll get many hours out of the base game alone, plus with the free upcoming expansion I'm sure there's many more hours to pour into it.Tl;dr - RTS game with many unique ideas/gamemodes, great fun and guaranteed to have a good time.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Gonna give this an upvote despite the numerous bugs as of 11 march 2016I used to love the sieges of total war med 2 , lotr rts and this game is what i was looking for Singleplayer :You colllect resources (sometimes within the castle walls) ,get to build up yer castle , put yer upgraded archers /trebuchets on the walls in prep for incoming enemy... kill them em off then counterattack and pew pew. Then most of the bloody bodies on the ground come back as zombies .The devs do throw a wrench into the game just as you think you are winning a mission to make it interesting.There was a mission where the enemy just kept coming and coming ...i was down to my last wall and they broke in , i charged at the orcs with whatever i had left but it was looking bleak. Just as i was bout to cry and fap over losing a 2 hour battle , a cutscene happened ...this was the way the mission was built ...has a lotr twin towers type ending then get saved at the last minuteBugs:there are tonnes of bugs , some can prevent you from completing the mission and you might have to start it all over again . I had a mission where i couldnt cross a bridge  and i was 4 hours into it. I actually did restart it next day , and same bug was gone .Your own troops seem unresponsive sometimes.Ive heard some people cant finish multiplayer coz the end screen doesnt come up. If you load a save , there might be  cracks in the walls you cant repair and enemy will just pour through themI addressed the bridge bug with a mod on the game -chat (there always seems to be a mod on to help people out) , and tried to help me out .Im sure they will iron these bugs out Graphics arent the best in the world , but i dont care too much .The singleplayer is only 5 missions ("New Episodes will be released as a free expansion pack, every few months." ) , but i spent hours n hours doing these.I also tried out a co-op mission and a survival mission (where u fight incoming waves of zombies). Every online mission you do gives you crafting rewards that you spend on cards (i.e. extra 2000 gold in game ) or the tech tree (giving you advanced troops for online play) and theres a sort of auction/trade button on the main menu

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								The pros- truly unique factions that are COMPLETELY DIFFERENT from each other, each requiring a distinct approch to building your base and fight battles. The gameplay of the elves is so different from that of the orcs you would think you're playing a different game!- very interesting siege defense and battles. There are very few AOE style RTS games out there that♥♥♥♥♥♥such an emphasis on siege elements, and this game does it quite well. Both defending your forts and laying siege on the enemy ones feel exhilarating.ConsNote that this game is still in early access stage. I assume and hope that some of the issues below will be fixed/improved. But it is always possible that they won't be. So I think people wanting to try the game should know about them.- this likely will stay, but it's not too much of an issue for me. The graphics is quite outdated for a 2015 game, even with everything on the highest quality. But for an indie game it's really not bad at all.- the most serious problem is the constant crashing. 9/10 skirmishes i played ended up CTD. The official solutions did not work. And that's when i have a good rig i7 + gtx 980 ti- some of the useful features that are omnipresent in RTS games are missing. E.g the game wont automatically redirect to  a unit after you press the number they are tied to, nor are they shown in a specific color on the minimap to tell you where they are.- your units can be pretty unresponsive to your commands. All in all it is a very fun game. Just hope the above issues will be fixed.

content:

Product received for free
												First and Foremost this is just an Early Review.  More of a First Impression than an in-depth tear-it-apart and tell you all it's flaws and greatness.I've followed this company and played their games since Kingdom Wars 1 was in Beta (Known as Dawn of Fantasy at the time), and aside from their recent hiatus they stand by their product which is more than you can say for most Devs in todays world.  Now let's actually get onto the game.They have taken the good things from Kingdom Wars 1 and squeezed them into a more concise game that should be more freeflowing and allow users to get right into the game.  WHich is really good and seems to work really well, however to me it takes a lot of the meat out of the game and I personally prefer KW1 playstyle over KW2:B.The Graphics aren't top notch but they're reminicent of RTS of times past that make you feel like your in a time machine.The Story is actually fairly decent, it's not the best writing ever but it's enough to keep you engaged to the point where you realize why you're fighting which is nice.The Music is nice but the sounds are more than a bit repetative, annoying the crap out of you when you click on NPCs/Peasants/Archers/Etc it is frustrating to hear the same thing over and over again.Lol, I meant to give a basic review and I went on a little much for what I intended.  Either way after I get some more time into the game I intend to extend this review to get some more depth.  I recommend this game, however I personally recommend Kingdom Wars 1 more, but why not both?!?!

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a conditional recommendation.The multiplayer is busted on all adversarial modes, the campaign is unfinished and the singleplayer lacks a great deal of enjoyment due to buggy controls and resultant lacklustre gameplay. I recommend either getting this game now and waiting for fixes, or buying it later, so the devs still have an incentive to finish their product.With all that in mind, here are the reasons you should buy this game:Units: The units in this game are large scale and yet have plenty of time for tactical diversity. Varying formations and abilities hark back to the good days of Total War, whilst the Stronghold-like maps are utilised well to create interesting battle scenarios. However, the aforementioned lag makes utilising a large-scale army near impossible and the clicks needed to fight most effectively simply cannot be dished out. Furthermore, the movement is basic at best, with units sometimes not moving to where you want to go at the right times. This can be especially annoying when it means losing half your army to someone pouring pitch over them or them walking into spike traps. What remains though is potential - with optimisation and bug fixes the unit system will be enjoyable. Conditional recommendation. Get it once this is better.Buildings/Economy: The economy system works well. Things are well priced and utilised well, with clear diversity between the races (more on this later). There is a mechanic called "trickle" where you get small-scale income from various buildings/units, whilst gatherers bring in large-scale resources. This provides a multi-tiered system whereby you can manage the short and long term economic needs of your settlement. Furthermore, the design of the buildings is clearly different for all three and provides more clear strategic diversity, with the settlement sieges being truly compelling and enjoyable at the later stages of the game. What's wrong then? Well, the game pre-sets where your walls are going to go, so you don't construct your own elaborate fortifications and they will be the same each time, with the same set-up, regardless of map. This means that in terms of defense, it can get quite samey. Furthermore, for all races but the elves, the ability to snipe resource points from outside the walls can make defending in the long-term impossible.  More needs to be done to ensure fortresses fall and aren't merely starved out in a 2 hour long staring extravangaza. Again though, there is plenty of potential for this to develop as the game goes on.Other: The races provide good strategic diversity in terms of their late game potential and ability but the cards and tech development is a bit of a sham. For a lot of the cards and techs, they do exactly the same thing but are just reskinned. I can't see this improving. TL/DR: Poor multiplayer. Broken campaign. Fun as hell mechanics though and plenty of potential. Put this on your wishlist and keep a lookout for improvements.

Early Access Review
								If you are an avid RTS gamer and hunger for a game that has something unique and different to the countless RTS games that have been released in the past, then I would recommend you jump on this developing one. Yes the graphics are not state of the art you see in recent RTS games, but the gameplay is above most that I have played in the past few years. And I'm confident that it will get much better due to the fact that the developers are extremely interactive with the community, asking players what they would like to see included in the game and how they would like it to develop. Most of the critical, "not recommended" reviews fail to understand or take into account that this game is still in development. Yes there are bugs and problems encounted but the devs are actively interacting with players and constantly fixing and updating the game.Yet, even in the present development stage, this game is fun to play with some very unique gameplay.I'm happy to stay on the "development ride" and looking forward to see this game achieve the success it deserves.

								Kingdom Wars 2: Battles is a nice RTS game with big interracial battles ( Humans, Orcs and Elves at the current stage) Castles  (upgradeable but given and not custom placable [yet?] ).Basically they took the MMO "Kingdom Wars" (free to play in steam) and transformed it into a RTS game. Also i recommend to play the free to play version for the undecided to get an impression of how the game looks like.If you like Stronghold and Lotr: Battle for Middleearth  - you should give it a try.Some points:+++ Close Dev contact via ingame Worldchat ( never seen such exemplary attitude in any game before )++ regular updates+ Castle siege+ Big battles+ Campaign+/- Orcs.Elves as playable races+/- Zombies as npcs+/- Technology has to be unlocked to be used in Skirmish mod- Graphics bit outdated and clumpsy at current stage ( actual version is 0.1.7) but for genre lovers this is acceptable and i bet they work on it- current AI is not the smartestAll in all it seems like one of those rare Early Access games which will actually reach something. Even at the current stage you have much fun in multiplayer and some hours in singleplayer. thumbs up

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								First of all, i'm not a native english speaker so you have to forgive me for any possible confusions. I decided to write a review for this game because the game is marvellous in all aspects with exceptions of a few annoying stuffs which will be summarized below.Pros:-Traditional RTS gameplay which consist of base building, economic management and fighting.-Variation of units and the very distinctive factions not a clone of each others or just a change in skins.-Each races have different advantages/disadvantages in resources gathering i.e. Humans can do husbandry and collect foods from fatten animals, Eleves instead gather food from picking fruits and let their deer generating supply and lastly Orcs can only hunt wild beasts or breeded animals for food. There are also other resources, gold, wood and stone to manage and each factions have pros/cons. Don't worry though the resource gathering/its technologies upgrade is simplified and cleverly done to not interfere with your fun in mobilizing your troops. These resorces aspect also affect your play style for each races for instance, Elves can generate every resources infinitely from tree symbiosis, alchemy and exchange market. In contrast, Orcs have to find a substitute gold and sone mining in neutral areas.-Supporting various play styles i.e. turtle, rushing or rogue.-Zombies, when you leave  corpses both yours and enemy's unattended, they will become the walking dead. Each factions has different corpse sweepers which more or less affect the battle strategies.  -NPCs and creeps, it is very fun to hunt down a dragon for treasury(additional resources which currently incollectible) or kill orges or goblins for dominating forward base/small fort. -Orcs produce units differently from other factions. If you guys remember the game named Battle Realm a decade back, these orc's units production reminds me of that game. To elaborate, you have to train different types of units by moving them through different types of buildings. -Sieging stronghold, you have to break through both outer and inner walls before destroying the enemy HQ. You can command various siege units which are vary for each factions.-Quite steep learning curve which for me is a plus as i'm having fun trying diffrent things.-Dev is quite active in fixing bugs and adding contents.Cons:( i will list it down from the most annoying/serious problems)-Units controls are quite lifeless and a bit clunky, you won't get a feel that you have already ordered your units. -No hotkeys at the moment particularly "attack move" command which really destroy the fun. -A few bugs here and there which are mostly under Dev's attention.-Incomplete contentsImo, this game deserves much better attention than most AAA RTS game released this year. The game itself have everything you can imagine a very good RTS should have and i definitely won;t regret buying it at full price.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												First impression review- under 10 hours.Its basially the RTS ive been looking for and I started PC gaming with warcraft 2.the graphics are a little wierd. (hurts my eyes at first, squinting and whatnot. im using a 55" TV and my glasses are scratched) but you get used to it and notice the GFX are decent.-edit-20 hours in... I think I left my game on... anyways. I get this feeling of Warcraft when playing. LIke warcraft 2 and 3 but a mix of age of empires and some TW... pretty cool.. This game currently has little lag for MP, from canada to au theres  ~ 0.1 second lag. not really a big deal. The huge battles make up for it. Orc for example has a pop of 80, and each 1 is 10 units I think..lol and you control 10 as a group.  Theres lots of upgrades and stuff like stances and formations that look really cool when you have 100+ units. They all level up and have personal upgrades too.This is made by a small dev team so if everyone could support them I think they will continue to improve this game and will make huge improvments each future game.plus free dlc/expansions. who does that? If you want TW but dont have the money or w/e and you can deal with less then AAA quality games then you should ppprobably get this.2nd edit-40 hours in. .. wow already? nice.. still enjoying it. need more players for sure. its a bit buggy.. random stuff.. UI disapearing.. building not spawning...Bunch of multiplayer games either end in desync, disconnects or crash.. but hey..TW games on sale... I really want to play them but I think..JUST PUNY HUMAN! ORC SMASH PESKY PEASANT!WH games on sale... but no sweet RTS building.Maybe I like it because my strat is unfair.. Rushing my orc archers at the start and using fire arrows to set my enemy on fire. Whist (while?lol) crippling his economy. Then spamming archers Ill soon have 500+ archers surrounding my enemies base setting everything ablaze. Your walls are futile. If you chase me ill run, if you get my archers ill change up my strat super quick, with one building I can change all my archers to polearm and bye bye calvary. If i need calvary my building is already built. since orcs eat their mounts., MMM lol. Not sure if it needs balancing or everyone is just new and cant handle the rush/spam. I wouldnt wanna be on the recieving end thats for sure. But really... archers autospawn for free.. literally cheap. Once they are going I have so much money to spare, while enemy cant even handle my cannon fodder ill be upgrading and spawning dragons and♥♥♥♥♥♥needs more players tho dangit, if you buy this feel free to add me, Ill go easy and teach you brosephs.*goods*+orcs,elves, humans  (talk about undead for expansion)+basebuilding+lots of units able to spawn+lots of unit types/upgrades/unlocks+can unlock the unlockable unlocks with singleplayer+zombies/ survival mode+seems to run decent performance wise.+map editor+custom games+++ active devs and mods*bads*-bugs crashes etc -missing little things... that I remember from old RTS games.. like lobbies, more game options... more user friendly friend system.-UI feels sluggish. at times I have to click again... its like the code for checking mouse input is on a fixedupdate or something.. I saw in the debug log about a input delay or something... not sure why they would add a delay so I will assume its not or its to help the game.-MP desync and some lag,-small user base means more SP.*Edit* 49 hours in... Honestly I have lost interest, I will try again if new content is added like they said. I still recommend it as that is more a review/rating for the game. For actually recommending it, I cant because I dont play it anymore because of player base and I am a very multiplayer oriented player, also some things bug me, like crashes, sluggish UI, and delayed unit responsegfx- 6.5fun factor- 8AI- 6.5campaign - Didnt play! id rather pwn newbs

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Hello, I would like to start off by saying that the developers and community managers are super friendly. They listen to the community on what they say and are working very hard in order to make a well balanced game and functional, yet fun RTS. This game has to be one of the most interesting and unique RTS's that I have played, and as a gamer that has played numerous RTS's can say with ease that this game has big potential. What I like about this game so far is that there is a crafting system that is enforced by simplying the game to further tech or enhancements.  The three races are currently, Orcs, Humans, and Elves. The game has a little bit of a learning curve and may hopefully be aidded by some simple tutorials or tip bubbles, however once the learning curve has been passed, the game opens up tremendously and is very fun. I rate this game currently 9/10 for the amount of content that is currently in game, however there are some small things that could be worked out. I would recommend this to anyone that is interested in RTS's or simply wants to have a fun game to play together with friends.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a really great concept. The other reviews pretty much voer everything I could say about the pros and cons of this game, so this review is more of me asking players and maybe the developers a few things. A. What is the point of the ruined forts outside of my city? I have taken them over and I'm not sure what the glowing volcano looking thing does inside the fort, I can garrison the fort, but is that the only use for it?B. Is there any way to attack a city without your men turning into zombies and making it nearly impossible to siege the place? I always end up having to fight the enemy archers plus my own zombies, which seem to be way better at combat than even my best soldiers, wish they were that good alive.C. (To the developers.) Can you please add a feature that lets you remove zombies? I love the game but always end up having to stay hiding inside my walls because whenever I go on the offensive I end up creating a zombie horde that surrounds my city and then random zombies pop out of the ground, making it even more impossible for me to leave my city.All in all, really creative approach to an RTS, lots of upgrades and unit variety, great siege battling. Buggy as crap, not optimized, and really weird unit pathing/combat, but that will be fixed I'm sure.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is an early access review so take it with a grain of salt.I really enjoy this game for a multitude of reasons.One of those reasons is the addition of zombies as a game mechanic in the game. It is something that isnt done in the RTS genre, and it really opens up different avenues of strategy in taking down the enemy base. Another consequence of this game mechanic is that it forces you to make sure that you have enough troops when exploring or else you will be overrun by your -former- soldiers as they die off.There are many other reasons why this game is great but they are commonplace in the RTS genre.Now, for the reasons why this game sometimes annoys me.- You need to unlock the tech tree for each race individually using items and other things found during your campaigns. This makes it feel grindey just trying to get the tech.- There are a multitude of bugs such as units getting stuck and units not following orders- Siege rams are way too op right now. I shouldnt be able to take down three gates with a single ram against a fully defended castleHowever, despite these cons (most of which can be fixed by either game balancing or bug fixing) this game is a definite buy.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												Okay, so I tried the game today. Graphics wise: I would score it at 5 out of 10 at max settings (could be better if sprites and textures enhanced), Overall Units Voice Acting: (I don't normally score this but, I think it could get better. Not that bad, just needs a little more) So, I give it a 4 out of 10. Story and lore: 7.5 out of 10finally gameplay (Campaign) 6 out of 10. Overall it's a nice game with some great potential. What I didn't like so far is the random game crash, like in the campaign mode. The SlowMo Feature for the game to slow down when multi-tasking is a bit too slow or too fast depending on who is playing. I would suggest having a game speed toggle to have it at 4 different speed levels which can be toggled at anytime just like slowMo Mode.The Flash fade in or fade out effect in story mode does hurt the eye. It was not just me who complained about it but friends who I invited to try the game out. Overall, I was beginning to enjoy the game when another crash happened during the 3rd human mission after the orc attack. I just hope this game has autosaves on some sections. But well, that's my review for now and I will post more as soon as I get some more hours-in-game.My scores are my opinion about that game so far, may change in the future but I'll be glad to hear your score and let me know. P.s. I'm just evaluating this from a Campaign story mode view for now. Overall I would still say it's a good game to try if you love RTS, Tower Defense and some good storyline. Think of Strongholds with a twist.Note: Gameplay would be scored so much higher if it doesn't have random crashes and If there was A WAY TO SAVE THE GAME in a middle of the campaign. Don't even make checkpoints as excuses. Not everyone has the luxury of time to play a two hour campaign then sudden something got messed up or your game crashes leading you to start all over. :(

content:
Posted: January 25
												Kingdom Wars 2 is an excellent game and has provided me with many hours of enjoyment just from playing the campaign alone. It runs without problem in 4K with everything but shadows maxxed out, in spite of many units and animations taking place at any one time. It is very competitively priced as well. For me, a key strength of the game is the interesting storyline, which takes several unexpected turns along the way. The injection of zombies is an unforeseen "X factor" in the game and is a delightful twist. Graphics and animations are well done, detailed and suitable for for the races and monsters. The makers have chosen a slightly more painterly color palette over the usual choice of "herioc primary colors", which is much more appropriate for dysmal muddy, filthy and downtrodden depressed mood of these imagined medieval times. To me, the game feels mostly like a great book that is very hard to put down again and I am recommending it to everyone who is a fan of the genre.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I had fun playing through Kingdom Wars 2: Battles, and am far from finished with it. But here’s what I’ve come up with from what I’ve done so far.I really enjoyed the theme of this game, letting the player slowly build up their own kingdom as protection from a siege. There are added challenges, such as food and materials, that you need to gather in order to be able to upgrade your buildings. There are very good tutorials to get you started on all the basics, and the game is laid out nicely enough that you don’t get confused with what you’re doing. Once you pass the initial teaching stage of the game, it’s onwards to limitless other parts of the game. If you finish with majority of the game, there’s even a steady stream of updates being released all the time.Pros:Great themeHigh quality graphicsAttention to detailConstant updatesFun multiplayerAwesome background musicHigh level of customizationLow priceSteam achievements and trading cardsLevel editorCons:Could get laggy at times (maybe just my computer)There was in-game rain quite often and grew annoyingCan get tiring after more than two hours at onceBut overall, it was a fun game to play, and a must have for fans of this kind of game. I will definitely be doing more playing in the future.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												Hands down, best strategy game I´ve ever played or seen. It is quite similar to Battle For Middle-Earth II, except this game has more realistic battle mechanics, especially archers - in this game, they are not OP, and you have no chance of succeeding in any battle with archers only. They do make a very useful support though - so, just like they did in actual historical warfare. One of the things that make this game stand out so much, is how amazingly detailed, scrupulous, and complex its siege mechanics are - there are ladders, belfrys, trebuchets, battering rams, mantlets, and many more contraptions and techniques in which you can break down your enemy´s walls, breach them, or bypass them. On the other hand, you can pour hot oil down from your battlements, or throw rocks, you can install catapults on them to help you defend, build high towers where you can place your archers for a tactical advantage, and more!I´m not going to lie - my first impression was a mix of confusion, disorientation, and frustration. This game is complex, hard to understand at first, and certainly can pose an intellectual and strategic challenge. And I love that. Once you understand how economy works in this game, and get used to controlling your troops, this game will show itself in its entire greatness.There are zombies, dragons, mages, mighty heroes, as well as countless other, less fantasy-esque units and foes. You can build a vast army, that will storm your enemy´s city and lay waste to it, or you can level up a few heroes, supported by a mage, who wreaks havoc with his powerful spells, and try taking the entire city on with just a few mighty individuals, much like in Battle For Middle-Earth.This game is absolutely worth its cost, not just the money, the time spent playing, the initial confusion, the effort you put in learning to play this game, all of it.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								There upon the edges of some ancient kingdom long lost to time, the settlers had staked their claim. A simple wooden palisade and a few buildings near rich deposits of stone and gold form the seed of what will grow to become a mighty city. Life is hard but the workers are harder, their lives, their future, and their hopes rest in them being able to survive. days go by and the people are exhausted but content for they are constructing their future, they are building not only a settlement but a legacy. As time passes scouts are sent to map the local area...most do not return. The wild is littered with ravenous packs of wolves and fortresses dot the landscape striking at any who venture too close. It has been decided, as the old mines run out and the stirring sense of adventure grows in the hearts of the settlers, it is time to claim their destiny. Armed and armored brave companies of soldiers ride out to meet those fell beasts. The hordes of teeth and claws fall before a volley of arrows and crash upon stalwart shields. The forts are besieged and the defenders rush out to defeat the brave warriors, but they to fall to the mace. As the soldiers break open the gate they swarm over fortress slaying the brigands and cutthroats. At the end of the day, when the banner of the new kingdom flew from the tower the settlers knew they had the grace of the gods. Word spread to the now mighty kingdom of an ancient elvish city in the far north, recluses who killed any who approached their gates. The people of the kingdom knew that this new foe would be a hindrance to any further growth, they too must be eradicated, such was the divine will. For months men trained to become the soldiers, the swords and shields that would claim the Kingdom's right to rule. Upon the field they assembled a legion of shields and steel... to the north they marched... to their destiny.10.1/10 would write inspired fan fiction again

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Kingdom Wars 2: Battles is probably the most unique and entertaining medieval RTS I have played in a really long time. The developers have continued to do a fantastic job of making changes big and  small  through communication with the players in the forums, as well as there own creative expertise, and its going to be a really really fun game when its all said and done. The graphics as of now are not the best, BUT its running on DX9 and it will be running on DX11 in the future, and it will look really good! Any complaints about no AI for the AI :p sound they like they are gonna dealt with in this next lineup of pathces and updates. All in all the zombies are a really fun addition to the battlefield, and seeing them wander around and do there thing is pretty cool, and alot of people bash them, but they add a whole different strategy to the game! you can lead a horde to the enemies gates and watch it attack the front gates and mob in through the mangles doors! Or my personal favorite: building a huge army and just charging over the walls and getting wiped out, but doing enough damage to let the corpses rot, and then wake up and start burning there town down from the inside! Honestly my only qualm so far is the peasents! They are SO stupid lol, and when you're playing against AI players that sit in there fortress its one thing, But I can imagine it would be very frustrating being in the middle of multiplyer game and all of the sudden have to divert all of your attention to stopping your peasents from being slaughtered in droves by a dragon, or the zombie hordes, or a HUGE pack of wolves for some reason, because they got bored doing what you wanted them to do. I really recommend this game to anyone that likes fantasy RTS games or wants to try something very unique and they like zombies, and/or knights hacking zombies to bits! There are alot of unique features and its definitely worth picking up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								A review huh?Out of respect for the developers I will write one,Now KW2 is a great game, some may not agree because it is an "Unfinished game". But as a player who has joined many of these said same games, I cannot stress how different this one is. The developers are EXTREMELY ACTIVE! Don't believe me? Look on the forums and click a random topic and you will see how.Now I remember when this game was first launced and how buggy it was, haha those who are vets know what I am talking about and all the glitches we all used to take advantage of. But the thing is, all the people in the player base post on the forums explaining in detail about these same bugs. Depending on how bad it affects gameplay depends on how much priority the developers give to fix it. When I say priority I mean those with a huge effect, developers try to fix it with the next patch, Those with low priority get fixed within a few weeks. Now those of us who were here since beginning had fun PVP and with campaign, but the game changers that EVERYONE mostly LOVES was the zombie feature. Haha I cannot tell you all how much fun I personally had in matches online with the zombies. The times in a FFA where 4 players are going head to head trying their all to take one another out, but alas due to all the deaths and carnage in the midst of the ruined battlefields undead would arise. Now in the beginning this was a major issue, personally I ♥♥♥♥ING LOVED IT!!!!!!!! Nothing more thrilling than that first player finally getting his base destroyed by your forces and wondering how the other 2 players are doing in their battle. Just as you are finishing up mopping uphis building in his base and of course handling the undead that appeared during your battle. As you are taking it all in you see either your base or the rear of your units taking damage. seeing it is a few steady stream of undead coming from the other 2 players side of the map. You cannot help but notice that the stream is getting larger and larger slowly forming into a horde, thus you must reorganize your troops before they die and add to the already large undead horde. Only once that you FINALLY (Ya those of you that had been in that situation know what I mean when you finally get them under control like an infestation) get the undead under control you decide to send a scout to see how the others are doing because these undead came from their end. Only to discover a massive horde beseiging both of their bases and them fighting for their lives against the AI. Ahhhhh haha I will never forget those beautiful games where all players put aside their differences of humans, orks, or elves and team up to exterminate the undead on the map before they completely take us all out.Those were proud memories I have of this game, memories that years from now as I get older I can talki video games to others my age or younger and tell them of a game that I really and honestly had alot of fun playing. Kind of like I do with Age of empires from when I was kid.Zombies now are a joke from what they used to be, they do not give that rush of a feeling but i guess in some instances it is possible to get that horde feeling even if it is just for a few minutes.-Wanderer

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												Kingdom Wars 2 review.In all honesty, this game has been extremely fun to play with my Friend, and even the solo campaign is quite fun. It's got a unique twist on RTS, it's largely defence/siege orientated, meaning that you get to build a massive citadel and fill the walls with archers! rain death upon your foes as they attack, but be careful! too much blood and death can spawn Zombies, and boy. The zombies? They keep coming, so you better be on top of them. Plus Dwarves! (although not playable, you can still get them.) Anyhow, enough of that stuff, let's hit the pro's and con's.The Pro's:+Good sound track+Enjoyable community and Dev's+Combat is fun+Build an unbreakable fortress+In depth Tech Trees and a nice Card System to assist you in the game.+Both of the above require crafting, and crafting is pretty easy in this.+You get ingredients from playing a game, win OR lose.+Nice art for loading screensThe Con's:-The graphics are somewhat outdated, but that is fine! it's a nice classical feel I say.-Not a huge selection of maps, but again this is fine as it is still fun!Overall I rate this game a 9.5/10 and highly recommend this to anyone interested. Definitely worth the buy, and most certainly something to keep you coming back! I strongly urge you to support the devs.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Okay. Maybe I was drunk on eggnog last christmas or something, I was way too kind to this game.Don't buy, not even on sale, not for now. I'll set your expectations:Pros: Good music and responsesConcept is interesting, at least, as you are encouraged to loot corpses lest they become zombiesOrcs, elves, humans play differentlyThe fun stops there.Cons:Lag and crashes. Read the Community Hub, where great gaming PCs stutter at 3fps for a game that doesn't seem to need bloom, anti-aliasing, or whatnot. Having thousands of units isn't an excuse, as older games handle squads and that many units without lag. That oldergame is BfME2, which is my next point:Game system feels like a clone of BfME2 that lost its polish. Levelling up structures, the cavalry infantry archer triangle, unit experience, heroes, all feel familiar but poorly executed.Tech and cards. By face value, cards are basically "choose your God Power" a la AoM. Because of the rarity of certain resources, you can get hit by someone with a free Hydra in multiplayer because he has that card, you don't have a counter. Tech runs into the same problem that AoE3 had: AoE3 was a great game, but having to play a hundred games while not yet unlocking all the good/necesary cards to WIN just to level up a Home city isn't fun, doing it for all other civs is a chore. For this game, it's a bit simpler, but it's still a chore to have to run at least 10 Skirmish games to unlock MOST of what a race can have. Now, some hope. Devs do respond, mostly. They update the game frequently, about once a month. They have a nice concept, and players appreciate it. It's not worth your dollars right now, and not even when it is on sale. When it does, I'll be among the first to sing its praises.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												I never got into the first one, so can't really compare the two, but I'm loving this game. As far as i'm concerned it's taken the crown off stronghold as best siege RTS. I was initialy dissapointed that you can't build walls wherever you want, but after some time playing I quite like that mechanic. It means you spend less time trying to line up walls and more time planning your defences and assaults. They've actually done a good job with the archers, where as in many RTS games they seel underpowered, in this game they can make a brilliant defence, and are something you have to seriously consider when looking to assault an enemy stronghold. I also like the unlock system. It adds a sense of progression to the game outside the campaign, and gives you something fun to try out after every few games. And the zombies are also a brilliant addition. I know zombies have been done to death, but never on this scale in a siege RTS. It's a cool little modifier in regular matches, giving you a reason to clear up corpses and making large battle sites a threat, and the zombie survival mode is great fun, and a different sort of challenge. Nothing beats loading up your walls full of archers with fire arrows :D

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												Created a Battle; Humans Vs OrcsHour 1:All seems well. My peasants are happily gathering materials such as stone, gold and food. I have captured a orc outpost, and have found some gold caches guarded by wolves. I made a stone wall around my castle, some turrets have mounted trebuchets on them.Hour 2: The Orcs have attacked me. I destroyed their siege equipment, and now my archers are slaughtering them by the droves. The Orcs have retaken their outpost, which is located close to my base. In both skirmishes i have lost a good amount of men.Hour 3:*hear moans* huh, thats some pretty bad orc audio. From the battlegrounds dead orcs and humans alike are rising from the dead. Undead ogres start to appear out of the fog of war.Hour 3.5:I have rung the bell of war. All peasants are now inside my base. All battalions are recalled, and everyone man, women and child armed to the teeth. My palisade wall is gone, and with it some of my hope. Zombies have come from everywhere, my walls are being attacked as we speak. My barracks are pumping out pikemen and swordsman.Hour 4:My first gate has fallen. I have sustained heavy casualties, but i think I have managed to stem the flow of zombies. I feel hopeful.Hour 4.25:My last gate has fallen. All the hope we had felt quickly turned to horror as men we had fought along turned into zombies.Their corpses re-animated. By making more men to defend against the zombies, we have simply given them more soldiers. I have lost contact with the orcs, I feel that they too are in a dire situation.Hour 4.5:This is the last entry, I have a small ring of pikemen keeping the zombies at bay. One by one they are falling, my wizard is exhausted, his spells have long been used up. He quickly stumbles, and is killed by the zombies. The castle is lost, overrun by the undead.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												When I first saw Kingdom wars 2, I couldn't believe it. It had everything I like in a game. Theoretically. It has so much potential. So many good ideas. The resource/card system is cool and adds a ton of different strategies, and other than a few balance issues its fun to play all the races.This game is so good, it has the potential to be my favorite game of all time. But it falls short with tons of issues.I had terrible sync drops in which I would be playing with a friend in the same room and our units would not be in the same place on the map, or his base would be totally destroyed but on my screen it looked perfectly tranquil. Game breaking glitches in which buildings that auto produce units, still continue to produce units after the buildings are destroyed making it impossible to get a strategic upperhand. It was so frustrating playing against my friend that plays orcs, and I harass and outplay him, but once his buildings are destroyed, they continue to make units and I could never make any ground.The zombie survival mode was fun, but after a few waves, my partner would always disconnect and drop from the game and so I end up just playing the rest out on my own anyway.The Campaign was the best part of the game, and thats not a good thing to say about this kind of game. The campaign should just be a tag-along to a fantastic online gaming experience.Overall, I would say this game is worth your time if you enjoy playing Real Time Strategy games. Or if you like building castles and armies and making your friends look dumb when you storm their weak and feeble peasants with knights or warg riders. I've had a great time with this game. I would have put more time into it if there was ever anyone but the one player that constantly beats me online.

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 25
												My 2 friends and I bought the game to play cooperatively, here's what we found out.Co-op mode is 2 players only. Survival mode is also 2 players only.That leaves multiplayer mode, which unfortunately is 4 max players, so that leaves room for 1 A.I. opponent. Which would be fine if the Hard A.I. was any good, but it's not competent at all.Connectivity is very junky, my friends could see my game, I couldn't see their's. Also Join Game via Steam is not possible.Our first game was a Total Annihilation victory conditon, which we coudln't complete despite destroying the enemy's main base, because some buildings couldn't fall below 1 HP. We couldn't deploy trebuchets because none of us had the required tech (which you unlock at the main menu) to build them, maybe thats why those buildings wouldn't fall, still very silly mechanic.We experienced heavy lag issues during gameplay at random times, the framerate would get choppy for a dozen of seconds and then it would go away. I suppose it's better than desyncing, but still..The biggest flaw in this game IMO is the terrible unintuitive UI. From a serious lack of shortcuts, to missing common features that you expect to find in any modern RTS (like when you want to add a unit to a group by selecting the unit and then shift+1 to add it to group 1, that doesn't work here), to frustrating moments when you can't find where your units are because: a) Center on unit doesn't prorperly work in some cases, especially on grouped units the camera goes all over the place.b) No messages at all of what is happening to your units, if they are under attack, out of stamina, low on health, where are they, what militay units are idle, you are oblivious to what is happening around the map if you are not looking around all the time. c) The minimap is just BAD. Some colors are hard to see, flare is always off from where you clicked, it's just useless.Also If a unit is engaged in battle, good luck retreating it. Some of them run properly, but the ones that are closer to enemy units, you literally have to fight against their suicide will by spamming the right click mouse button until they (hopefully) get to your base.Finally, from the 2 multiplayer games we played, we encountered some bugs, one of them was a very obvious one: 3 units from a larger group suddenly were stuck on a hill where there was no path to it (was pretty funny when it happened though).From my experience this game lacks some serious standard RTS features, needs a UI rework, better A.I. and tactical unit behaviour. It would also benefit from bigger maps with more opponents (4 players is too low c'mon) and a rework of the Survival mode to allow more players to enjoy some zombie horde slaying. Honestly most of the positive reviews here were misleading to say the least, whereas the few negatives were spot on.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
Early Access Review
 Disclaimer - I have been gifted a free key for this game for review purposes, however my review will be kept as truthful as possible, since I am meant to help developers and buyers/gamers. Kingdom Wars 2: Battles review Graphics KW2 has some very impressive graphics that sadly require one meaty boss of a computer to even go on medium settings. However the game's still beautiful even on the very low settings. So all that it would take is some improved optimisation to make the game more playable. I can play 99% of games on maxed out setting, but this game only runs on 25fps, so that will make KW2 to lose a few points. Apart from poor optimisation, the game is a masterpiece, no questions needed. Although you don't always get to just stare at this work ofart for too long as there is always action to be seen. Gameplay This game is like the Total War series (the good games of the series), Clash of Clans (for a giant amount of things you can build) and Company of Hereos had a marvelous baby. You can build tons of different thigns (each race has different buildings), there's a campaign mode, a gigantic variety of classes (every race has different classes), different ways to gather up resources (races have different ways to get them), different advantages and disadvantages throughout the races, multiplayer, singleplayer, and so, so much more content. So to tum this topic up, if you like a lot of content in a game, this is will fullfil your expectation even more than you could wish for it to. Races There's currently 3 classes. Humans, Orcs and Elves. Humans are the most basic class (and the most boring)... why would you want to choose them? Well, maybe if you're new to the game you will choose them. The second class is Orcs, just as you might think, some really cool guys who are violent, much like the Vikings but in a beast form. Last but not least, there's Elves! These guys might look boring, but if you play as them, you'll know how powerful they are. They can technically have never ending resources with only a bit of work. Also, they have unicorns... fantastic game 10/10 - Wolff. So hopefully in the future we'll either see some workshop content or more races such as... uh... something. Building Think of Sid Meiers' game series and Rome: Total War 2s' mechanics inside of one masterpiece. As already mentioned from my description, this game has an excellent style of building. There's tons of buildings, upgrades, walls, and a bunch more items that you, the player, can use to either an advantage or disadvantage. As you can build, the opposition can do the same. And if you can attack, you can destory. Does that give you a hint? Yes, you can invade others settlement and completely destroy it. After that, you can do an even more horrible thing and loot the townsfolk that you have just slaughtered for different loot. Pros vs Cons Pros:In depth buildingGraphics are jaw-droppingVery funUnlike other gamesTech tree'sSingleplayerMultiplayerCampaign modeRacesClassesUpgrades Cons:Very poor optimizationBuggy (this should be an excpetion since it's Early Acces, but there's too much bugs) Overall score 8/10 - Even with lots of bugs and bad optimization, it's still an excellent game. Worth picking up once on discount, even if you're a non-gamer!If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group  Check out the Original Network Groups. Win free games, make new friends on Steam, & more! Original Curators Group [ttp],  Original Traders Group , &  Original Giveaways Group

								The game has a lot of potential. Still needs a lot of work, I had to post via review because the chat box wouldn't allow me to converse back with developers, during gameplay.  I got the game because it stated, it would have a coop option, but unfortunately, that option isn't there yet. I wish I had more freedom with the maps, unit color freedom, and it seems that regardless of what map you pick, you're still pretty much in the same spot (single-player mode) ....you can branch out to other parts but don't have the ability to restructure as you would in AOE. When clicking on "idle workers icon" it will highlight them, but doesn't seem to take you to them, so unless you are on top of area, you won't see the highlights....causing me to have to hover over wherever i see my color, in order to hopefully see highlighed workers. I did like how the workers came out in batches.  Aside from the lack of player freedom on the map....I have to give it two thumbs up for design. There is a lot of creativity and I love that there are a lot of building elements not found in other strategy games. For example, the ability to have troops utilize the watch towers.  Conclusion, this game has tremendous potential, and I was very pleased with the creativity that went into it. I will just practice patience and see what comes of it.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												I'm not going to complain about the graphics; they are more or less what is advertised in the screenshots. Dated, yes, but marginally improved over KW 1.I initially gave this game a thumbs-down, citing it was unpolished, buggy, and generally a mess. Matches were unwinnable, in a number of ways. Content was limited, maps were few in number, and the primary game mode was a half-finished survival style of game.I'm happy to say the game has been significantly improved since then. Yes, it's still a bit ugly (perhaps more specifically dated looking), has a clunky UI, and seems to ignore mouseclicks every so often. What it does do is provide an enjoyable gaming experience, within the very specific realm of a survival style siege defense game. The competitive multiplayer I haven't played much, but judging by comments, continues to go in the sort of balance circles we've become familiar with in recent years. (Rock OP, Paper is fine. -Scissors.) I don't consider the patches and fixes they've released for free to be a glorious gift, full of exciting new content, but they are still patches and fixes, a sign that the developers are committed to continuously improving and expanding the game. Kingdom Wars: Battles has always been a game for a specific nice sort of player, looking for a particular experience. However, it's gone from being a lousy way to fill that niche to being a satisfying and enjoyable one.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												Kingdom Wars 2 provides a brutal but satisfying RTS with a campaign that will carefully beat into your head the importance of slow, careful preparation. Fittingly for a game set in a medieval world, the elaborate fortifications that sprawl across key points of the map are crucial when it comes to holding and expanding your territory, and building up proper defenses first and foremost, both in campaign and multiplayer. Watching a ramshackle palisade grow, bit by bit, into a proper stone castle manned by hundreds of archers and swordsmen never gets old, along with seeing the enemy break on it.Additionally, the three races within the game all manage to be unique in both mechanics, playstyle, and design. The Humans are the most "standard" faction, training troops from buildings and taking resources from the map. Their workers are fragile, their units work wonderfully together, and their defenses are incredibly strong.The Orcs automatically spawn workers from their buildings, which are then sent through "training" to become stronger units. Their defenses are lacking, but their troops are strong, with their workers able to fight at range and in melee both, serving as their basic infantry.Elves are an interesting case, having one of the strongest economies, but otherwise unremarkable defenses and soldiers. The ability of the elves to spend money to make more money, without having to send their workers outside their defenses, is quite powerful, and allows them to build up massively if given the chance. Their greatest strength is their "monstrous" units-massive ents, for example.The Undead, fittingly, completely change the game once they show up. In Skirmish and Campaign both, they seemingly come across as a minor creep faction that can be dealt with easily, until they swarm you in the aftermath of a major battle and you realize every single corpse can and will become another enemy. Relying on the day and night cycle to combat their spread is crucial, before they turn into an existential threat.Lastly, while the graphics are seemingly lackluster, they serve well enough and allow the game to throw together truly massive battles with troops in the tens of thousands, with the only limitation being how big you are willing to make your army.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												The developers have added a lot of content since when I first bought it, which was awhile ago. As a player of RTS style games for many years now, I can safely say this is one of the greatest indie RTS games I have played. In fact it is a solid RTS, for the price, and I haven't really seen anything that was comparable.It features:Progressive Gameplay; I.e. upgrade talent tree that is outside of the actual battles. You gain loot and such, then spend it to gain benefits, such as a knight, or spearman, buildings, etc.Common RTS elements and uncommon RTS elements, all that are good. Base building, troops, management of resources. Uncommon includes choosing to grow chickens vs pigs, to send a cart or not, where to build a farm, how to use the resources. Do I use the wood for this or that, what do I use the stone for, the gold for, do I use food for peasants or soldiers? Each match (this was awhile ago, sorry if review is outdated), plays out with a strong tactical gameplay set AND elements normally limited to turn based games. The maps are fair sized, and there are plenty of objects to go for. Want more gold, get a cart, some peasants, and send them out to mine. You may need to station soldiers nearby to protect them from enemies, including the undead.Speaking of the fallen, things that die have a tendency to, well, come back to kill you. If things are left unlooted, which must be done by peasants, they will come back and be an annoyance. At first this seems trivial, but can be abused to cause injury to your foes. Raid the neutral camp near your enemy's base early into the game with a medium sized force. This way if your troops succeed, a large dead force will strike at their peasants and fort, and if not hopefully many die, and the same result may happen to your foe.Neutral camps, the enemies vary, usually protect resources that you need in order to survive and expand, and are worth looking into.The game is somewhat complex, and has bugs, but is definitely worth the investment.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
Game's InformationGenre: Indie, Simulation, StrategyDeveloper: Reverie World Studios, INC Publisher: Reverie World Studios, INC Release Date: 5 Mar, 2016IntroductionKWB2 has greatly outdone itself in portraying this game into giving users the feeling of being directly part of the game. It brings us back into time during the viking ages that makes me just want to attend cosplays for these. KWB2 offers Single & Multiplayer modes, making the game ever lasting. The Dev team has only four members working on the game and they work hard as they listen to the player's suggestions, despite this not being a game genre I would play, it certainly did made me addicted and wanting to spend hours continuously managing my units. GraphicsIt has outstanding graphics and the animations done has greatly displayed it's quality development by the developers of the game. I was greeted by the loading screen which grabbed most of my attention, giving me the anticipation of how action packed the game would be.GameplayUpon the start, I explored the campaign mode. It mainly focuses on humans battling against the orcs. Each level is told with a backstory which gives more meaning to the battle, making us more encouraged into winning the battles. I tried multiplayer mode for a short while and found it rather the star attraction of this game. It gives the opportunity to replay the game once they've completed campaigns modes, which never lets the game die down. I tend to get entertained by the not so professional players causing mistakes in the game as well. It comes with a Single player mode where you can run in your own adventures or do survival modes. I've yet to tried out Single player hence I wouldn't be able to run a brief overview of the game.ProsGives a acient feelingRuns on multiplayer, increasing the replay valueFantastic graphicsGreat audio and musicInteresting backstoriesConsWhen opening my overlay, the game crashed (several times)Some lag issues, possibly my PC being a potato on startupAudio being broken during startup (Due to the lag)I would strongly recommend KWB2. Some plus benefits is it having trading card and achievements to keep a person coming back for more. With a hands-on development team regularly updating the game, this title is a great addition to any library. Get it today to stop missing out the fun.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												So I am going to go on a whim and write this review purely on opinion and not on gameplay. Firstly, there are two main grouped sub-categories of people who will like this:1) Medieval/RTS fans will find this game unique, and kind of follows a old-school style of play where you primarily build up your base in one main location. If you like the Medieval/Fantasy theme that is also a bonus2) Players who can get over polish and odd textures. Yes, this game feels a little "clunky" but since this a review I have to be real, the game is still a little clunckly. But the interface and fantasy animation effects are only a means to an end, and that the game does require more polish. The animation for some units especially when they are attacking or mining a resources looks terrible, it just doesn't look right nor professional. However, since I've played a large variety of games, I've learned to ignore those visual effects and focus on the gameplay itself. Gameplay: So the reason I am giving this a thumbs up review is because I feel like this game does bring something unique to the table, it's a real-time base-building/ siege simulating strategy game that involves zombies. Now, that is quite creative as I don't play many medieval/fantasy games that involve zombies (well I guess if you play a lot of fantasy there is usually a necromancer, but nevermind that). Anyhow, the siege aspect of the game is very unique and I do feel like I am playing in the realm of some medieval world in how much preparation is needed to breach a wall. So here is where the cons come in, and this is very important because this list of 'bad aspects' of this game is what throws most people off when they first buy it (I bought it at the original price of 29.99$ on Steam despite numerous other sites that sell the key cheaply because I wanted to support the continued development of this game).1) At some point in time when playing this game, your going to get lag spikes, on some rigs it may never go away. The game engine seems to lack the integrity either to handle newer machines or it is just in general bad coding. I'm not an expert so I'll just leave it at that2)Again visuals and animations do not look fantastic, there is an endless amount of games I could list that have amazing visual effects for units in RTS games when it comes to mining, dying, spells, fighting, etc. etc. Kingdom Wars 2: Battles will need to desperately mend this problem if they wish to appeal to hard-core RTS fans since this is a major draw to the game is the pretty graphics, especially animation. It just looks sloppy and some of them look like they repeat a different action.3) Tech and boasts locked behind "play wall". So quite similar to a paywall where you pay real money to unlock certain tech and stuff in a free to play game, King Wars 2: Battles thought it would engage its playerbase by locking new tech and upgrades behind what I call a "play wall" during the main menu of the game. Meaning, you'll have to grind in this game via singleplayer, multiplayer, or whatever to gain gems, chests, or whatever resource in this game that could be only obtained from finishing a full match in this game. You can spend said resources on the main menu where there is myriad of unlocks for the three races presented in this game. Some people don't have time for this grind and it just puts you off because it feel force feed of "yes we want you to play this game a very long time to get everything" versus most RTS games put the tech and upgrades inside the game via a special building like a blacksmith, engineering bay, etc. But nope, not Kingdom Wars 2: Battles, they want to put a play wall instead of putting it inside the game where you unlock all these things inside the match like most RTS games do. 4) The zombies aspect is not fully fleshed out, and quite frankly it needs a lot of work. Sometimes it doesn't feel it's working right and at other times the AI for the zombies is just stupid. Like it feels they attack anything and anyone, they don't have really anything special about them. They just feel "there" and you can't direct them in any sort of way in the game. You would think since this is a kind of a reference to a fantasy/medieval type theme, the three races in this game would at least attempted some way to use the zombies as a weapon against their foes. Nope, instead they are just FFA type enemies that spawn after troops are killed in battle via your or the enemy side.5) UNITS: This is a big problem for me, I do not like the way each unit is grouped and bunched with each other. A lot of RTS has a unit spawn, say, a barracks one by one, and not in a group for a reason. In a RTS games, you will want to mix somme elements with another via drag and click and group them to hotkey in the form of 1 2 3 4 5. . . . . However, in Kingdom Wars 2: Battles all the units spawn in groups, so really when they are walking around your castle etc. they may get stuck, and in other times it is confusing when you are running a siege because  you just have all these globs everywhere. 6) Sieges and AI feel really bad. I mean sometimes the AI can attack you REALLY early, and sieges are really hard to manage. It just feels feels like a grind breaking down the enemies walls and fighting their army, and vice-versa once your base is invaded you pretty much lost.VERDICT: Yes I gave this game a thumbs up, but I did harshly criticize some of the design decisions of this game. King Wars 2: Battles does bring something new to the table and they took everything from a RTS game and completely took a different direction. It will heavily depend on whether or not the player can adapt to these changes. On a more positive note, the developers are constantly updating and supporting this game no matter how much flak it gets or how much people bicker and cry how about this game, they love this game like it is their baby, and I respect that. I also felt I had a valid reason for making these criticism since I did pay a premimum price for this title only to support them, and they did lower the base price to 18.99. However, I will praise this studio, they aren't giving up, and despite all the commotion and "rioting" they still struck on to mold this baby into the soon to come master-piece they envisioned. This game has come a long way, from early access, now to a full-released product, and they still say, were gonna work on this game and show everyone that were not going to stop until everyone is satisfied. I kid you not when I say a lot of other studios would have quit and thrown in the towel, probably put a premium price tag  on their game and disappear and years down the road suddenly release another game. I've seen studios who have done this, simply abandon one game and create aother one when the first few months look bleak, and often times their catalog of games always have the same mixed review rating because of vicious cycle. But not Reverie World Studios, INC. they stand by their product and look to truck away onwards and upwards until this game meets everyone expectation, and for that, I thank you, and say good luck.
