content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game... I wish I could say good things about it I really do, but it's just bad. This is an impulse buy at its finest. The single player maps are just you with the NPC already having a base made and ready for attack (mind you it's not a campain map) My first playthrough went a little like this...Start out inside wooden walls, build a few villagers and tell them to gather the resources, basic stuff... But then it gets better; I build an archery range and buy some bowmen. There are a group of neutral ogres just chilling outside my base, so I use my bowmen (just made, lvl 1 no upgrades) to kill all 8 of them, just kited them around and thought "well that was easy" but then I scroll to the left a bit more and there are a **** ton of wolves atleast 300 of the damn things. Thought "Maybe this will be harder". (When have you ever know wolves to stay in a pack that big?) regardless... my bowmen wipe them out easy no problem (Still the same bowmen, lvl 1 no upgrades) so after my 20 bowmen wipe out 300 wolves, I decide to actually build my base. First attempt I build a mill, villagers get stuck inside and I have to delete them... After that I build a house, villagers get stuck again, delete them also....  Then I quit the game, just couldn't take it anymore, and proceeded to play Age of Empires.Pros:The devs seem nice I guess ++Exit button is easy to find... +++Cons:UI: Non existent UI (Only when the building is selected and its just an eye sore) --Units: all the same and walk like a bunch of dumb stiff♥♥♥♥♥♥♥---Tutorial: I said "What?" and "Why am I doing this?" too much... (They tie it into the story instead of trying to teach it was just way TOO MUCH) --Story: Orcs ♥♥♥♥ed everybody in the world and are suddenly stopped at the "last" human city? REALLY? (If you have free reign over the world you would NOT be stopped at a single city) --Graphics: I'm not a stickler for graphics, but seriously? IT LOOKS EXACTLY THE SAME AS KINGDOM WARS 1 --These positive reviews are too misleading, I was hesitant to buy this game but they sold me into it. I should never have purchased this game and I would love a refund. I really, REALLY would...

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												Good game with an interesting mixture of popular RPG mechanics. 3 diverse and fun to play factions, Humans which are your typical jack of all trades faction with good defense and offense but not the best at either. Elves which are your best defensive faction because of their self-sustaining economy and strong wall fortifications, also invisible archers which are a pain. Orcs which are supposedly good at rushing but it doesn't normally work out for me, thankfully the orcs are also a strong faction in mid game with powerful offensive units, I believe they are the only faction with non-siege units that are effective at breaking gates down (ogres and minotaurs). There are also 3 mercenary unit factions that are fun to play around with (Dwarves, Dragons and now Undead). The gameplay is fun as feels like a mixture of Age of Empires, Stronghold and other classic RTS games. Graphics are outdated but you get accustom to them in time, especially if you are an old-school RTS player. Be warned this isn't a game you should jump directly into multiplayer in, its highly advised you play at least some of the campaign missions and some skirmish games first. As their is a tech-tree system that requires different crafting components you use to invest in. I believe you start with a fair amount of crafting components now to research some of the tech tree but this is an important point because without the tech tree research, you will be at a large disadvantage in multiplayer and unable to build the majority of your units / upgrades.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Due to the system of techs and cards which require resources you gain from playing and most likely losing, the best way to eventually win at this game is to intentionally lose repeatedly. Your AI opponents have access to all the good stuff right off the bat, but you're as helpless as a babe in the woods. You won't make it through the tortuous tutorial campaign unless you are the kind of person who loves being wide awake while the dentist laughs evilly while he drills on your morals, so you enter the game clueless. You haplessly build up a city thinking that you are doing all the right stuff and all of a sudden your opponent(s) have dragons ripping you a new anal orifice. Dragons? Where the f did they get dragons? I'm still trying to figure out how to mine more gold, you say to yourself.  This game is an incredible lesson in humility, because you cannot win without losing, a lot, first.My inner masochist gives this 10 thumbs up.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												This game has the nice concept of adding zombies into a RTS as an added treath to manage as you fight against your enemy. The greatest problems is that it fails on everything else. Here my Pro/Cons list.~Pros:∎ Zombies will rise from dead bodies, trying to kill everything comes near, they will siege castles and swarm and block some paths, requiring to add new strategies constantly as the battle on the field evolves;∎ Three factions with detailed and big unlock trees that makes possible to customize your army with different kind of units;∎ Survival mode: zombies will rise and attack you in waves, each wave bigger and stronger.~Cons:∎ Poor and low aestethically interface with a poor "trade" function (you can trade crafting materials with other players) where it's not that clear who is buying what and for how much. Luckily I didn't fall in that but have seen lots of people trying to exchange 'a golden palace for a few copper coins';∎ FPS drops even on high end computers (probably no problems on the last two models of nvidia) when you select units, leaving the game frustrating, most of the times unplayable;∎ Unit commands don't respond as they should, sometimes they don''t get the command giving you the sensation of them lagging because of the input, most of the times you have to double or even triple click;∎ Some units are cheap and letal, they allow you to stack different platoons of them together and bugabuse by clicking one command to decimate an entire army (noticed it with a spell that shuld only stun enemy units, not damage them), some heroes are ridicolously OP;∎ Dragon has a problem to attack enemy units, he doesn't react and when he does he ends up breathing a cone of flames where your unites are not, making very easy killing him with just a couple of archers;∎ Poor selection of maps, a couple of them are just a copy/paste with and without snow, with a unbalanced resource/camps distribution;∎ Most of the bugs are there still from the release date, some gets fixed but it's not enough.In the end the game could be good, it has potential to be something different than the usual RTS, the dev team is following and requesting actively the community to signal bugs wich is nice as it shows their will to try to fix them all creating a better game... But that's not enough, at least for a game that values 27.99€ on Steam, in my opinion they should take them eyes off the old game and focus on this because one good game is better than two mediocre games.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
Product received for free
												Before I start, I must put it out there that I'm not a fan of RTS type of strategy games. I've tried many titles in the past, but I don't seem to get attached to any for some reason. This particular one, however, was more fun than I've anticipated it to be.After clicking the play button, Kingdom Wars 2: Battles (KW2) offered 3 different choices (Play Game, Game Options and Scenario Editor), each of them serves different purposes as you may have noticed. One thing to add here is that the Game Options screen allows players to select the game’s resolution scale, which the in game menu lacks the ability to. The game apparently only support full screen window mode, as mentioned in the forum by one of the developers:Originally posted by Dev Konstantin:That option is actually Full-Screen Windowed mode, so unfortunately this is not the windowed mode you want to see. We can`t add a real windowed mode without weeks of work reworking the engine. Sorry. Regardless, the Options Utility does not work at all for me. But that isn’t much of a big deal; I’m fine playing the game as it is. For those of you who prefer playing in a small window, just so you could alt+tab and do your own thing while playing the game at the same time would find it very much unlikely to do so.Kingdom Wars 2: Battles enables players to train their own troops and assign tasks to attack or defend from their opponents. The campaign mode felt more like an interactive building management rather than a lore-extensive story mode, but it shouldn’t matter much, given that the game didn’t choose to be a roleplaying game. The game has a decent tutorial to prepare those who aren’t familiar with the RTS genre and made sure that players get to experience different sides of the battlefield, playing as the humans, orcs and elves. On another note, the MMO part of the game adds more to the single-player experience with various features, suitable for those who enjoy working together with or challenging other players. As mentioned by other reviews, the developers are very active in the forums. They could’ve stopped giving support for a released game, like so many other developers at Steam. By listening to the customers’ concerns and answering inquiries of those in trouble, it shows that the developers truly care about their game and the community itself.I believe that the developers’ dedication towards improving the game with only a handful of staff is remarkable in and of itself, and for that, I truly think that this game deserves a chance for those that are interested into trying this out.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												A Decent game. Although The graphics are not spectacular, there are some bugs and glitches, units are hard to read, and rough, but still responsive controls, The gameplay of this game is really fun! Why is this game fun; because you can play with your friends in survival mode, You can play against people in 1v1 games, you can do team battles or awesome free for all mode, you can literally siege your opponent base with siege towers, trebuchets, catapults, many more siege weapons and the battles are messy, but Epic, the combat is pretty fun too, which make the game more engaging. Even the zombies make this game fun because if your or enemy units die then they have a chance of becoming a zombie which could hurt you more or your opponent if you don't deal with the corpses.Yes, the game have generic fantasy tropes and have ton of generic rts mechanics, but there are few original mechanics like the card system, tech system and the MMOlike elements of guilds, trade, and social. Even though this game is average, I think average games are sometimes worth the purchase. And this game is worth it. Really interested in what the future for this game. Hopefully they add in more PVE modes, more campaign missions, and add steam workshop to Kingdom Wars 2 someday.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I played and liked the predecessor "Kingdom Wars" and so i was sure that now KW2 will be even better... but well, it is not.I am not going to write about bugs and bad AI, because I know what an early access game is, and that this will be fixed in the future.But I can allready write about the gameplay and the direction which the game is heading. And personally, I dont like it.The grafics, the animations, the soundeffects, the music, the units, everything is just copypasted from the predecessor. KW1 was played like an browser game, where you builded one big city and could attack the cities and armies of other players or AI on a big world map. So you had a big city building part, and a big fighting part.The developers said in KW2, they will focus on the battles. And now you are building a base, gather ressources and fight at the same time against up to 4 players on a small map, just like on every other RTS game.By abandoning their "city building" part and mixing it to a smaller scaled skirmish together with the battle part, they not only decreased the actual game content, but also their unique feature, that made them standout from the rest of the RTS games. Another thing is the grinding system. In KW1 you had a gold currency, which you could buy for real money, or earn on the battlefield. From the gold you could buy new technologies and hero-units. It was actually a pretty fair system, since you got a fair amount of gold for defeating enemy units.Now you dont grind for gold, but for up to 10 ! (or so) different resources-cards, which you get randomly for every fight, and which you need for unlocking new skills, technologies and units. Of course you will always need the right combination of them to progress and some of this cards are very rare. Also mind, that you will have to unlock everything for the orcs/elves/humans separatly. In the old grinding system, you knew what you get - gold - and you could buy with it whatever you wanted.Now you get something completly random, that you maybe dont need at all and allready have in large quantities. There is a market where you can trade your resources-cards with others, but of course everyone is trying to sell you his stuff as high as possible, so this doesnt really help.Except for the new grinding system, the only new feature right now, are the zombies. after some time, the corpses of the fallen soilders will rise as zombies and attack everyone close by. This can be fun, but also quite annoying, depending on the players. You can deactivate the zombies in the options if you want.Conclusion: The exact same game, but - right now - with less content and a much more tedious grinding system than before.

This game will never match my hours spent on C and C back in 2014, but this game really holds it's own, since buying it I really have become hooked. Just need more of you to notice this gem and to build a strong community of gamers. They really are working on this game. They have another update coming next week... definetly worth the 13 pounds.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												I must admit, at first, I was lost. Goes without saying that if you get creamed in the 1st act of the campaign which doubles a tutorial..we'll. it's a bit complicated. LOL. So I went and played a scenario, got the hang, got the feel, and the more I did the more I loved it. Very uunique gameplay and a stunner for a strategy/RTS fan. It's like stronghold and HOMM had a baby...a pretty one. From the castle work, to the leveling up of individual troops with stats/traits, resource point capture/defense and base building...it all ended up being quite fun and immersive in the end. Yes it takes a bit of learning curve but what good game doesn't.  As for problem reviews, I did crash the very time I opened the game...then never again. I had no in-game problems, no studders no anything so far with quite a few "Learning hours" under my belt. I'm just on win 10, which hasn't been updated sine the anniversary patch, an R7 230 card, and a amd A8 7600 Apu, with 8 gigs of ram. So ceertainly not a powerhouse computer and everything has ran fine so far. I also play MW3, COD BO2, Stellaris, Euro Truck Simulator 2, Battlefield 4 and quite a few other graphic intense games with no problem, crashes or lag. So, take the crash reviews for the hit/miss they are. The game itself, is awesome and enjoyable, challenging and engaging. Well worth the mooney I paid and certainly worth a shot.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												started off shaky due to the game not recogising the nividia graphics and using the intel graphics instead lol but dev dudes noticed that bug and said its gonna be fixed so flipped from impulse negative review to thumbs up senpai noticed me review! haha, but anyways if your games shaky and laggy just check your graphics options and add it to your gaming graphics.as for the game, the chars graphics seem pretty basic, probably due to making up with the amoun that need to run and process, the blood and corpse effects are cool, and makes it even cooler when you set zombies to high. the zombies in the game make it unique to other RTS games as the fallen enemies or your own troops can rise as zombies and cause problems for everyone, meaning its usually more beneficial to die and do the killing in the enemies area to avoid the whole pooping on your doorstep and causing zobies to rise on your land, so it adds consequence to death and battles. which adds a furthur strategical layer, i even saw some big moster troll thing rise as a zombie in a enemy castle which pretty much stomped anything he had left.game still gets a bit laggy late game, probably due to me turtling with lots of units and letting the ai build too much and spamming houses.walls are pre built and set in position and you can upgrade to make more get built or upgraded, which is neat as it means you dot have to dilly dally making shoddy walls yourself like in other rts games.it has cool weather effects and thick looking stormy rain, but i turned those settings off to prevent lag and it still looks good without the extra effects.all in all a cool rts so far. will update if i find anything else and change review as necessary XD

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												Well, i don't like to write bad reviews, but new people should be advised about this game.Regarding the Pros and Cons:Pros: + Zombie addiction: i think it's the most beautiful thing in a rts game: with big battle you can turn the field in a bloody horde of zombie that will go to attack your base and everything they will meet, you need to burn them or send your civilians for cleaning the bodies or the zombies will spawn every time. + I like the 3 factions: they are different with their pros and cons, they made them very good.+ The economy system is good: you have to collect wood, gold, food and stone.  But you need to choose carefully your strategies, because gold and stone are limited if you don't build the other things for collect the resources ( each factions have their way to do it). + Battles are great and funny, you can build from soldiers to orcs, monsters and everything else (it depends from your faction). + They are working hard for improving the game.+ Mod kit is coming for early julyCons: - Lag: there is lag when you play with more than 1 AI or versus other players. This is a bad thing in the game, it ruins a lot your game's exprience. - The map variety is not so good. All the map are similar, and they need a re-balance for the resources nodes.- Ai: Despite the last improvements, it still needs a lot of work.Conclusion: Devs are trying hard for improving the game, but they are a small company, so it needs long time before having a 'full and complete game'. They lowered the price, now it's only 18 euro in my side. I still don't suggest to buy the game in it's currently state, but if you love the idea behind and want support them, then buy it!.I will update my review, but for now it's negative. Hope my English is good, i'm sorry for that.Edited: 22/06/2016

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												From what I understand the game is still being improved and patched. Currently it is playable and enjoyable and truly is innovative for a medieval fantasy RTS. Music is good too. Scale is more realistic than other RTS. But several things still need to be fixed. Movement and controls are not as crisp and smooth as other RTS. There is too much need for double clicking, especially when commanding military units. Doesn't feel as responsive as a crisp AAA RTS. I have top of the line hardware and software but still the game has the abovementioned issues. Graphics are very good and cinematic mode is VERY fun and cool. Combat animations should be improved. Make it like battle for middle earth where cavalry can trample enemy units. Make the graphics more customizable and deeper graphics options than simply low medium high etc... Make it more sopshisticated and customizableTreant's graphics are sub par, they could look ALOT better. Some other units need improvement in appearance. Make combat unit animations more fluid and diverse and less robotic and clunky. Make it like Battle for Middle Earth, where cavalry and large Units can trample other units and push through them.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												First advice, take a look in the bugs section of steam discussion. It's huge!Bought it for about 6$ and the game was fun in campaign for a while. But it has a lot of bugs and some are gamebreaking. It uses only 25% of a quad cpu and stutters like crazy seemingly out of nowhere and there is no fix for it other than a seemingly bad engine. Pathfinding is also very buggy, units get stuck in walls, rivers, under bridges etc and make your archers shoot at them forever. I played it for about 30 hours but half that time was trying stuff to solve the gamebreaking stuttering.The devs are pretty active but they seem to spend more time selling the game with borderline false advertising and moving all bugreports away from the general discussion that they use for a "sales channel". So take a long good read in the Bug Reports section before you buy.I didnt even get around to try the multiplayer which i read is pretty bad (you dont play the same game because of desync issues).This game and the way the devs answer the "unknowing" potential customers gives me a lot of "Red Flags" aka the WarZ case. Even the voiceover guy sounds like he is about to burst into laughter at any moment and he gives you the feeling that you are playing a parody.Stronghold 3 and Stronghold Crusader 2 are much better games and all the Age of Empires. Heck, even "Craft the World" are better spending time on. Dont even try comparing this mess to Warhammer.

												Sorry, can't recommend this game. Her's why:1.) No Pause-ButtonI like to build my Keep an defend ist. Thinking carefully where to spent your rare Resources and what Unit to build and where to place the Unit. There's only the "Slow-Motion-Feature"  which ending me playing the whole game in slowmo, what is rather redicilous. Me personally can't even read the discrption of what differnt Buttons dp and what Upgrades they prduce before pounded to dust... and that's on Easy-Mode and Slow-Mo...2.) Same goes for the Second Point. I hate, I really hate games with "Timers"... e.g. You have X-Minutes before Y happens... Mainly that means attacking something... and as mentioned before I like to play from a strong Base. E.G. Securing a Strong Base which can defend itself, perhaps produces some Resources and than turn over to the Attack Mission. That's not, at least for me, possiple.3.) The Suvival ModeThis could be funny: Facing endless Hordes of Undead until you finaly go down... but all Cards are the SAME. You can select e.G. Desert or Coastal Cards... but... they all the same only with different textures... and by the way, because of 1.) and 2.) I didn't survive the firts Night (with the Humans). The Elves are somewaht easier because the Resources are in their Keep and not outside like with te Humans. The Orcs I disn't try.4.) Online Connection RequiredI hate it if Games are requiring you to be online to play. Sure, there is a button to turn ths "feature" off, but first yoz have to be online to start the game, get to the Main Menur and hit this f*cking Button. Personally I think this Online♥♥♥♥♥♥is  a very-very-very bad modern thing. I don't give a damn about Multiplayer, why san't that be respected?Okay... if you like fast Action and do have a very high Frustration Treshold than maybe you could get some Fun out of it. But for me it's certainly not the right game and therfore I can't recomed it.Technically it seems okayGreeting from SwitzerlandRobert

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												So, I have been looking for a proper RTS game with alot of managing and keeping an eye on your troops while thinking of proper strategies.This game is one of those games that will provide you with indepth tactics and strategies while maintaining a steady income of supplies and training troops. There are dozens of upgrades, not to mention boost-cards  that you can craft with materials you get when you play the game. Yes, by simply playing the game. No micro-transactions, just by playing the game. And you get those quite regularly. After every lose, win or every 3 waves in survival.There are 3 factions with each their pro's and cons and these weigh up and off eachother. I have fallen in love with this game, simply by it's simple graphics, deep gameplay, friendly community and really, really good developers who are still working on this game and are planning another (FREE) expansion!I suggest you buy this game because this is the RTS that can provide you with hundreds of hours with gameplay.

												This game, is broken, if ya gotta get and play any game similar to this, just get Black & White or Age of Empires/mythologythey are better.My problems with this game is that, the AI for your soldiers, are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, during the first act the very first act, i understode all of it cuz im not new to these types of games (altho being forced to create a whole platune of soldiers And workers is a bit odd but understandable) but a broken AI is fkn broken, i had set up my soldiers, towers, oil, trebuchet strategic and perfect, i figured out right away that the enemies would most likely scale the walls with ladders or what not, so i made sure i had soldiers placed to block off their access to the stairs and the towers where my archers were located, the battle started and as i figured, they scaled the walls, pretty obvius....But, then i noticed that the AI didnt do a damn thing, the orcs just walked right past my soliders, neither giving a damn about eachother (no i didnt tell them to hold attacks, that'd be dumb) and went right for my oil and archers, even when i told my soldiers specificly to attack the orcs and their ladder....they didnt do anything, they ran Past the orcs, to the ladders, started climbing the edge of the walls basicly standing in the air outside the walls, and my archers were firing at the damn ground for some reason, not that the enemies had just happend to walk past there oh no, they were firing on corpses or something, it was basicly unplayable trying to command your men, if you've never played any other Strategy game, this could be acceptable for you, if  you've played basicly any other, this will be torture to try to play, a great idea and could be one of the best...but it needs A LOT more work put into it, atleast the AI needs to be fixed thats #1 priority to be taken care of.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
Product received for free
												Kingdom Wars 2: Battles is a RTS with an interesting crafting system entwined with classic RTS gameplay and a great story.The Story:The story in Kingdom Wars 2: Battles is a great one pitting Humans against Orcs from the get go. The cutscenes are narrated with quality dialog making it feel like you are there commanding the forces and overcoming the challenges. The setting is somewhat different from other RTS games due to Human forces being on the defensive from the invading Orcs. To avoid any large spoilers I won’t go further into detail  but it is a story that will keep you playing.Gameplay:Now gameplay is where any RTS shines the most. There are several ways to overcome a challenge like instead of scaling walls with ladders why not smash it in with a battering ram! There are plenty of units to complement anyone's play style. The crafting aspects enhance the gameplay further giving you an edge over your enemy.In today’s internet age no game is complete without multiplayer. Kingdom Wars 2: Battles has your multiplayer RTS needs covered with intense PVP or co-operative play. There are also free content updates no season pass to get the latest chapter or added content! So many great things but every game has some bad mixed in with the good. The tutorial could have been longer and more in depth on certain mechanics. Resource management takes some getting used to. Overall it was still one of the best gameplay experiences in months for meBugs and Glitches:No game is perfect bugs and glitches happen they are fixed Kingdom Wars 2: Battles has only a few annoying bugs. One cutscene bugged forcing me to close the game.There are some visual bugs also like textures stretching in weird ways. The bugs and glitches are mostly minor and don’t lessen the gameplay or story quality at all.Pros and Cons:Pros: Great storyCrafting systemCard battlesIntense battlesMultiplayerMultiple unit typesVoiced dialogHelp menuMultiple ways to overcome a challengeFree expansion packCons:Small visual bugsTutorial could be better Resource management can be tough for those new to the gameThis review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For similar reviews and fantastic giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Okay, I usually dont write reviews, but i simply had to make one here, since most people seems so thrilled about this game.I do realize that it's an early access game, but even with that in mind I wouldnt recommend the game. (Basicly I'm against paying for an unfinished product because it removes the motivation to finish the game). I bought the game because it was supposed to be a mix of Total War and Stronghold. IT IS NOT.Well, first of it is VERY buggy, and when i say VERY, I mean VERY buggy. It took me almost 3 hours just to make the game launch, and when it finally did it lagged alot during the intro scene and narrating.  It annoyed me so much that i had to quit after only 20 mins of gameplay.Since this is early access you would have to live with a few bugs, thats true, and the bugs arent the reason why Im not recommending the game. But besides this being an early access game, it simply looks and feels like it was released 10-15 years ago. Animations are ugly and the game feels clumsy. There is no real introduction to the game, so you just have to learn by playing.Game graphics looks like a mix of The Settlers 3 and Age of Mythology, with the feel of Age of Empires II. Might not sound like a bad mix, but for a game made in 2015 thats just not good enough.I asked for a refund, think and research before you buy this game.

												So, I was looking for a new RTS with castles, swords and bows. This game instantly caught my eye! The developer videos looked amazing and the graphics were nice. The AI is unrelentless, I have been playing some single player on easy and I get rushed and harrased so bad. Perhaps I am not as good a player as I thought but normally on easy, the AI doesnt attack so much and plays more defensively.I am going to bear with it but at the moment I am not so sure.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								My first thoughts: I rate this knowing it is only in... From the looks of things hopefully still on the drawing board and not in Alpha stages. My first play through was the screen coming up 'connection lost to server' and closing down the game to the desktop, half-way through a game. No warning or option to re-connect.After my third attempt I actually managed to play the first campaign map. After completing it and going on to the next chapter... well that was blacked out and only allowed me to repetitively play the first.If I could think of any Pros I’ll list them…. Hmmm, nope.Cons-Graphics. The graphics strongly compete with up and coming games of the late 90’s to early 2000’s like Stronghold. At first I thought my resolution was 600x400, but on checking and zooming in…. mobile games have better graphics…. And that’s no joke. Whilst graphics aren’t everything, having trouble distinguishing an orc from a human on a 27” monitor at full zoom is concerning.I never played the original Kingdom Wars but thought it was something akin to Dawn of Fantasy, that’s entirely my fault and a mistake I’ll never make again.I see no point continuing to bag this game as it’s still in early (hopefully WAY early) development. But for the current price, I wouldn’t recommend to anyone to purchase this refuse even if it was on sale for under a dollar.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												Kingdom Wars 2: Battles is basically the same game as Kingdom Wars (the original game). I feel like the developers could have a really fun game here if they added new and better features. Why not have more units and buildings for your kingdom? Why not make the maps bigger? The crafting in the game is a good idea but was implemented terribly. You only have 5 spells for you wizard? Not cool. Only having 4 resources makes the game boring. Not to mention that they run out quickly then you have to rely on the market for your resources which by the way is supposed to work on supply and demand (it doesn't). Having a population limit of 80 is really boring as well. Last and the MOST IMPORTANT...  You need to add mod support. For the love of God... Mod support.This game should still be in alpha. I can't recommend this game until there are some serious changes, unless its on sale for $5.

content:

Early Access Review
								I can't really recommend a game that tries to be like Stronghold Crusader, but doesn't allow you to move any of your castle buildings. Want a wall in a specific spot, too bad. Want a tower over there, so sad. To be fair, I did see some reviews that listed this as a problem, but they were a month or two old, so I thought this might be something they added. Failing that, I thought that maybe it was designed well enough to compensate for that. The battles just felt kinda samey after a while. Also, I hate the card system. I like being able to unlock upgrades, but you literally start with jack squat at the begining. I'd like to have seen it be at least a little well-rounded. Also, if you spend some cards on a race you realize you don't like, then sad day for you too. The cards should be split among the races. In other words, the humans should have their own card deck, the elves should have theirs, and so forth. That way, if you don't like one of them, you can always switch races and still get some upgrades.

number of helpful: 1 of 9 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												I did not enjoy my brief experience in the game. I had thought this would be a nice construction based RTS, which I like quite a bit. And it's true, the construction is a highlight of the game. Watching the walls go up, expanding the walls, and reinforcing the walls with defences is very fun. That was the only fun part of the game I could find.The many bugs made the game frustriating. the graphics are painful and the saturation is driven up to hide it. The UI is a mess. Units aquire skill points, which means you have to go to each group of units and distribute their skillpoints one at a time. The AI is bad, and the neutral outposts seem to be pointless.The Combat AI really made it unplayable though. Telling melee units to attack a unit, they will attack exactly that unit, and only that unit, even if they need to walk behind 3 lines of enemies to get to him. You can't even form a wall to prevent the enemy from walking past you, not that the AI would anyway. Just stick with archers who at least autoattack. Worse, there are no formations or advanced orders. The best you can do is tell your units to form a line facing one direction or another, making combat tactics paper thin.I expected fewer poor design choices and bugs from an indy studio.Pros:-Cool wall construction and upgrade machanics ++-Old school style resource collection +-Old school style unit design+Cons:-Bad map AI, Worse combat AI --Blinding graphics and saturation ---Frustrating glitches --Lack of formations or complex strategy ----Old school unit design -Verdict:Don't believe the fanboyst. Unless you really want to built walls stay away, even at 50% off.

												I can't really tell if it is a good game, or a bad one, but it has one of the most annoying bugs I have ever found in a game. Once I started the game, I was happy that there is a Campaign mode. I like to start new games with these. It started well. but it seems like my peassants don't like the pig meet. One of the first step is to slaghter pigs. And they do it well if I tell them to. They kill a pig, and every one of them is happy. The become so full of themselves that after that they do nothing. I need meat to train units, but the peasants don't like to carry meat. They only like to kill the pigs.After the 3rd start of the campaign, I gave up, it seems like I am terrible ruler, who can't even tell the peasant what to do...EDIT: After the Gods have intervened for the sake of this humble ruler, our subjects did their jobs deligently. Alas we have alredy given up hope on the human race, but will try our best as an Orc Warlord.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 9
												Kingdom Wars 2: Battles has three different races to it.Although I can not say I have fully played the Elves or humans, I have played the orcs for a while and enjoyed the gameplay.The gameplay itself is very fun and with a few updates I'm sure this game would something I would reccomend without a second of doubt.Except there are a few issues.1: Not all workers have hotkeys, meaning you have to use your mouse for it. For people who really want to be quick, this can take extra time as well as all other RTS games having hotkeys for these sorts of things.2: Elves in annihilation mode right now appear to be unkillable.3: The mouse being small can sometimes get lost in the middle of big battles, making it hard to direct troops.4: You have to unlock your techs for multiplayer mode, and there is currently no way to quickly check if you're going against a person with 300+ hours or a person just starting out when doing 1v1 or coop (Aside from checking their username in the social tab).Besides that, I'd reccomend this game for anyone looking to buy a fun RTS, it also has a great and entertaining Campaign.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Awesome Game, despite the outdated graphics it's one of the most fun games I've played in a while.There's a lot of love being put into this game, the Devs are active, friendly and sometimes you can even play with them.In versus mode there are a lot of tactics that can be deployed against your opponent, the zombie system (too many dead bodies piled up result in zombies spawning) can be used in your favour or sometimes screws you up big time if you manage to defend an enemy attack but don't get rid of the bodies quick enough :)Survival mode is extremely fun if you manage to find someone who works cooperatively with you to defend against the endless zombie horde.The races all have a very different feel to them, there are many units and upgrades to choose from and with the resources you earn after each battle, you can unlock even more stuff like cards that have a limited use and act as spells to give you an advantage.The only downsides are the occasional (but rather rare) crashes and the currently low player count.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												I've been playing RTS games since I was young around 5 or 6 and now that i'm 25 i've had some experience with the genre. This game is a great for strategy, You can really get into the finer details the more you play it and it keeps you entertained. There is only a few things I can think of to make it better and that is more factions, units but not like in the total war games where you have to pay for everything and self placed forts. Other than these This game is a great game and just needs more advertisement and following for it.
